illusobjdesc.#text: The subject of the design may be Genesis 5:22: "And Enoch walked with God after he begat Methuselah three hundred years, and begat sons and daughters."  A low dais or plinth consisting of two steps runs most of the way across the bottom of this design, from the lower left corner nearly to the lower right corner.  It forms a kind of stage for the scene.  Four tree trunks rise at regular intervals above the dais, starting from the left edge of the design and proceeding to the right edge of the dais.  Each tree bears a leafy canopy just visible below the upper edge of the design.  Vines climb the three rightmost trees.  Indeterminate, perhaps leafy vegetation fills much of the space between the two leftmost tree trunks.  Between the three leftmost trunks a distant landscape of low grassy hills is visible.  A lake may be located just below the hills, and a near bank below that.  Wash above the hills, between the third and fourth trees, and to the right of the fourth tree suggests the sky.  An old man, apparently Enoch, is seated near the center of the design, on a kind of dais.  His body faces forward, with his bent knees out toward the viewer.  He turns his head to the right and tilts it back slightly, so that his face is visible in profile looking up to the right.  His slightly bent left arm is forward, and he rests his left hand on his right knee.  His bent right arm is also drawn forward, and he grasps one edge of a book loosely with this hand.  The opposite edge of the book is propped against the folds of his garment on his right thigh; his left hand may also help to support the book.  The old man casts a dark shadow on the dais to the right.  To the left of the old man reclines a young woman, probably one of Enoch's daughters.  Her lower body extends to the left along a bench or couch, and the shape of her garments suggests that her bent right leg may be crossed over her left.  She twists her upper body forward at the waist and rests against a pillow or similar support to the right, visible beneath the old man's right elbow.  Her right arm is down and bent across her torso.  She turns her head slightly to the right.  A young man, probably one of Enoch's sons, rests in a similar position just to the left of her.  Two children sit between them.  The man's lower body extends to the left, but he twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward.  He turns his head right so that his face is visible in profile.  The man wears a long gown and has long curly hair.  His right arm is bent and drawn forward, and rests on the right shoulder of the foremost child, a girl.  The girl's shoulders face forward though she turns her head slightly right.  Her right upper arm is extended down to the left, while her left upper arm is down.  She has long hair and wears a shirt or gown.  The rightmost child is a boy whose head and left shoulder are visible to the right of the leftmost child.  The boy's shoulder faces forward, but he turns his head to the right.  He has short curly hair, and may be nude.  The partly erased head and upper body of an additional figure appears, facing right, above and slightly to the left of the head of the female just left of Enoch.  The couch on which the four people sit extends to the left.  Shadow fills the area beneath the couch.  Two youths stand together near the left edge of the design.  One is slightly to the left of the other, and partially hides his companion.  The leftmost youth faces right and rests his weight on his right leg, which is planted on the lower step of the dais; his left leg is bent forward and drawn up, and his left foot rests on tiptoe on a higher step.  His right arm is down by his side but drawn forward slightly.  He holds an object, perhaps a book, in his right hand.  He is nude with visible genitals and has long curly hair.  The partly hidden youth to the right stands on the highest step of the dais, facing forward, but turns his head to the right.  His left arm is by his side and seems to be bent behind his back at the elbow.  He may be nude or may wear a short tunic.  He has short curly hair.  A grouping of five angels is visible at the right side of the design.  The foremost angel hovers or flies facing forward and left, but turns his head farther left so that his face is seen in profile looking left.  His left arm is down by his side and bent forward at the elbow, and he holds one corner of a piece of paper, possibly a scroll, with his left hand.  The angel wears a gown or tunic draped over his right shoulder, leaving his torso partly nude.  His mouth is slightly open and his long hair flies behind his head.  He partially hides a second angel, whose head, right arm, and right shoulder are just visible above and to the left of the first.  This second angel's right shoulder may face partly forward, but his head faces left and is bent down slightly.  He has short curly hair, and may be nude or may wear a gown or tunic.  His slightly bent right arm is extended forward from his body at roughly 135 degrees and he holds the other end of the large paper with this hand.  Marks on the paper suggest a text, possibly Hebrew letters.  The third angel from the right in the front group of three, who is partly hidden by the other two, stands or hovers facing forward and slightly left.  This angel's slightly bent right arm is extended and drawn across his torso to the right; it is hidden below the elbow.  His right leg, visible below the paper the two foremost angels hold, seems similarly to extend down to the right.  He has short curly hair and may have a small mustache.  The heads and shoulders of two more angels appear together in the upper right corner.  Of these, the shoulders of the angel on the right face left, but he turns his head away so that his face is not visible.  He partially hides the angel on the left, whose left shoulder seems to face away though he turns his head back towards the viewer.  Shadow fills the upper right corner of the design, extending down the right edge.  Shadow also fills the space beneath the foremost angel's gown.  A few odd forms upper right, only sketched in outline, hint at serpents.  There may be a chair sketched in outline just right of Enoch.

p.#text: The subject of the design has often been described as Job and his family (see Related Works in the Archive).  Butlin 146, however, identifies the subject as Genesis 5:24.  An earlier passage, Genesis 5:22, seems more likely: "And Enoch walked with God after he begat Methuselah three hundred years, and begat sons and daughters."  The identification of the design's subject and its textual basis are tentative.

illusobjdesc.#text: A low dais or plinth consisting of two steps runs most of the way across the bottom of this design, from the lower left corner nearly to the lower right corner.  It forms a kind of stage for the scene.

Four tree trunks rise at regular intervals above the dais, starting from the left edge of the design and proceeding to the right edge of the dais.  Each tree bears a leafy canopy just visible below the upper edge of the design.  The leftmost tree sprouts one branch.

Four tree trunks rise at regular intervals above the dais.  A vine climbs the tree second from left, circling around the trunk once.  It bears several sketched leaves to the right.  It may send a thin branch up the trunk above the loop.
Four tree trunks rise at regular intervals above the dais.  An ascending vine loops tightly several times around the rightmost tree.  It may bear several sketchy leaves.
Four tree trunks rise at regular intervals above the dais.  Indeterminate, perhaps leafy vegetation fills much of the space between the two leftmost tree trunks.

Four tree trunks rise at regular intervals above the dais.  Between the three leftmost trunks a distant landscape of low grassy hills is visible.  A lake may be located just below the hills, and a near bank below that.

Four tree trunks rise at regular intervals above the dais.  Between the three leftmost trunks a distant landscape of low grassy hills is visible.  Wash above the hills, between the two rightmost trees, and to the right of the fourth tree suggests the sky.

An old man, apparently Enoch, is seated near the center of the design, on a kind of dais.  His chair or support is not visible.  His body faces forward, with his bent knees out toward the viewer.  He turns his head to the right and tilts it back slightly, so that his face is visible in profile looking up to the right.  His eyes may be raised.  His slightly bent left arm is forward, and he rests his left hand on his right knee.  His bent right arm is also drawn forward, and he grasps one edge of book loosely with this hand.  The opposite edge of the book is propped against the folds of his garment on his right thigh; his left hand may also help to support the book.  He wears a long gown that falls to the floor.  The toes of his right foot emerge from beneath its hem.  His left foot may be just visible to the right.  He has a full beard and long white hair.

An old man, apparently Enoch, is seated near the center of the design, on a kind of dais.  He holds a book in his lap.  We see the top or bottom edges of the book, its pages surrounded by the binding.
An old man is seated near the center of the design, on a kind of dais.  He casts a dark shadow on the dais to the right.

An old man is seated near the center of the design, on a kind of dais.  To the left reclines a young woman, possibly one of Enoch's daughters.  Her lower body extends to the left along a bench or couch, and the shape of her garments suggests that her bent right leg may be crossed over her left.  She twists her upper body forward at the waist and rests against a pillow or similar support to the right, visible beneath the old man's right elbow.  Her right arm is down and bent across her torso; her right hand is hidden.  She turns her head slightly to the right, so that her face is visible in three-quarters profile looking right.  Her eyes are raised and her mouth is open slightly.  She wears a long gown that seems to have a high waist or perhaps a belt.  A scarf or cloak covers her head, falls behind her shoulders, and drapes down her lower body over her gown.  Her long hair hangs over her shoulders.

A young woman reclines along a bench or couch to the left of the old man who sits at the center of the design.  The low seat extends to the left on the dais.  A pillow or similar support rests on the bench or couch at the right end.
A young woman reclines along a bench or couch to the left of the old man who sits at the center of the design.  Shadow fills the area beneath the couch.

A young woman reclines along a bench or couch to the left of the old man who sits at the center of the design.  A young man, possibly one of Enoch's sons, rests in a similar position just to the left of her.  Two children sit between them.  The man's lower body extends to the left, but he twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward.  He turns his head right so that his face is visible in profile.  His right arm is bent and drawn forward, and rests on the right shoulder of the foremost child, a girl.  His right hand may dangle, or may rest against her arm.  The man wears a long gown and has long curly hair.

A young woman reclines along a bench or couch to the left of the old man who sits at the center of the design.  A young man rests in a similar position just to the left of her.  The heads and shoulders of two children are visible between them.  The leftmost child is a girl whose shoulders face forward though she turns her head slightly right.  Her right upper arm is extended down to the left, while her left upper arm is down.  She has long hair and wears a shirt or gown.  Her mouth may be open slightly.
The partly erased head and upper body of a figure, facing right, appears just above and slightly to the left of the head of the reclining female left of the bearded old man.

A young woman reclines along a bench or couch to the left of the old man who sits at the center of the design.  A young man rests in a similar position just to the left of her.  The heads and shoulders of two children are visible between them.  The rightmost child is a boy whose head and left shoulder are visible to the right of the leftmost child.  The boy's shoulder faces forward, but he turns his head to the right.  His mouth is open and his eyes may be raised.  He has short curly hair, and may be nude.

Two youths stand together near the left edge of the design.  One is slightly to the left of the other, and partially hides his companion.  The leftmost youth faces right and rests his weight on his right leg, which is planted on a lower step of the dais; his left leg is bent forward and drawn up, and his left foot rests on tiptoe on a higher step.  His right arm is down by his side but drawn forward slightly.  He holds an object, perhaps a book, in his right hand.  He is nude with visible genitals and has long curly hair.  His eyes are raised.

Two youths stand together near the left edge of the design.  One is slightly to the left of the other, and partially hides his companion.  The leftmost youth holds an object, perhaps a book, in his raised right hand.

Two youths stand together near the left edge of the design.  One is slightly to the left of the other, and partially hides his companion.  The partly hidden youth stands on the highest step of the dais, facing forward, but turns his head to the right.  His left arm is by his side and seems to be bent behind his back at the elbow.  He may be nude, or may wear a short tunic.  He has short curly hair.  His mouth seems to be open slightly.

A grouping of five angels is visible at the right side of the design.  The foremost angel hovers or flies facing forward and left, but turns his head farther left so that his face is seen in profile looking left.  His left arm is down by his side and bent forward at the elbow, and he holds one corner of a parchment with his left hand.  Text written on the parchment faces out.  The angel wears a gown or tunic draped over his right shoulder, leaving his torso partly nude.  The skirts of the garment swirl around his legs.  His left foot is visible dangling in tiptoe position below.  His mouth is slightly open and his long hair flies behind his head.

A grouping of five angels is visible at the right side of the design.  The foremost angel hovers or flies facing forward and left.  He partially hides a second angel, whose head, right arm, and right shoulder are just visible above and to the left of the first.  This second angel's right shoulder may face partly forward, but his head faces left and is bent down slightly.  His slightly bent right arm is extended forward from his body at roughly 135 degrees and he holds one end of a large parchment paper with this hand.  He has short curly hair, and may be nude or may wear a gown or tunic.

A grouping of five angels is visible at the right side of the design.  The foremost angel hovers or flies facing forward and left, and holds one corner of a piece of paper, possibly an unrolled scroll, with his left hand.  This angel partially hides a second angel, whose head, right arm, and right shoulder are just visible above and to the left of the first.  The second angel's slightly bent right arm is extended forward from his body at roughly 135 degrees and he holds the other end of the large paper with this hand.  Marks on the paper suggest a text, possibly Hebrew letters.

A grouping of five angels is visible at the right side of the design.  The third angel from the right in the front group of three, partially hidden by the other two, stands or hovers facing forward and slightly left.  This angel's slightly bent right arm is extended and drawn across his torso to the right; it is hidden below the elbow.  His right leg, visible below the parchment the two foremost angels hold, seems similarly to extend down to the right.  He seems to wear a tunic that leaves his right shoulder nude.  The folds of its skirts are visible to the left of the angel's right leg.  He has short curly hair and may have a small mustache.  His eyes are slightly raised and his mouth is open.

A grouping of five angels is visible at the right side of the design.  The heads and shoulders of two appear together in the upper right corner.  Of these, the shoulders of the angel on the right face left, but he turns his head away so that his face is not visible.  He has rather long, curly hair and wears a gown or cloak.

A grouping of five angels is visible at the right side of the design.  The heads and shoulders of two appear together in the upper right corner.  The angel on the right partially hides the angel on the left, whose left shoulder seems to face away though he turns his head back towards the viewer.  This angel's mouth is open.  He has curly hair.  Other details are not clear.

A grouping of five angels is visible at the right side of the design.  Shadow fills the upper right corner of the design, extending down the right edge.  Shadow also fills the space beneath the foremost angel's gown.
Some curving lines upper right corner of the design hint at the bodies and heads of one or two serpents.

Job sits with his family lower center, holding a book or 
tablet and gesturing with his right hand.  His wife is to the left, 
holding on open book on her lap.  Six of Job's children sit, lie, and stand on the right; one holds a scroll and another a book.    
The figures are seated on what appears to be a long, low bench.  A dog sleeps below the part of the bench on which several of Job's children sit.  Two winged angels hover lower left; both hold scrolls.  
Behind the family group are two trees with vines and clusters of grapes entwined around their trunks.  A flock of sheep grazes in the left middle distance; behind them is a mountain peak.  Another complex figure group appears in the heavens 
above, partly contained within cloud bands left and right.  At the top sits God with radiance behind his head and upper body and an open book on his lap.  He points downward with his right index finger to Satan, who 
hovers, striding vigorously to the left, in flames.  Also in the fire are the faces of Job and his wife.  Four angels hover on the left side of the group; one deposits a book before God's throne-like chair, while another holds an open book.  
These figures are balanced by a group of five on the right, including an angel placing a scroll before God and another holding a scroll.

title: Satan Before the Throne of God

illusobjdesc.#text: The foreground is grassy.

Job sits with his family lower center.  His hair and beard 
are long; his bare feet appear beneath the hem of his 
gown.  He faces forward with his head turned to the left, and holds a book or tablet between his left hand and left knee.  With his right hand he gestures downward and to 
the right, fingers spread.  His head and eyes are turned slightly 
upward.
Job holds a book or tablet.

Job's wife sits to the left of her husband.  She is gowned 
and her hair is long.  She faces forward, with her head and eyes turned slightly to the right and downward. 
Her arms are bent and she holds an open book on her lap.
Job's wife holds an open book on her lap.

Two winged and youthful angels hover lower left.  
                     The front-most angel is gowned and holds a scroll in his upturned palms.  His hair is short and curly; his body faces forward and slightly to the right, and his head is turned to the right.  Both feet are visible beneath the hem of his gown.
The two winged and youthful angels, lower left, hold scrolls in their hands.

Two winged and youthful angels hover lower left.  
The rear angel, almost covered by his companion, is gowned and holds a scroll 
in his upturned palm.  His hair is long; his body faces forward and to the right, his head is turned to the right, and his eyes look downward.  His bare feet are visible.

One of Job's youthful sons sits, half-reclining, just to 
the right of his father.  His hair is short and curly.  He faces forward with his head turned to the left, and is nude except for the bit of drapery covering his lap and right shoulder.  He holds a 
scroll in his left hand.  His right leg is bent at the knee before him, his left leg extended to the right.  His bare right foot is clearly pictured.

One of Job's daughters is the second figure to the right 
of her father.  She is seated and half-reclining, with her left arm at her side.  She appears to be nude, and faces forward with her head turned slightly to the left.  Her hair is long and curly.

A young boy appears as the third figure to the right of 
Job.  We see only his head (facing forward and slightly to the left) and 
shoulders, which are undraped.  He is probably sitting, like the two 
figures to the left.

A youthful and nude male stands, facing left, as the second figure from the right in the foreground.  
His right leg is bent at the knee, his left arm is bent at 45 degrees, and he holds a book in his left hand.  His hair is short and curly.

Behind and to the right of the seated female is another female figure, of whom only the 
head and shoulders are visible.  She is gowned, has long hair, and faces forward with her head turned to the right.

A gowned female figure 
with long hair is pictured at the edge of the right margin.  
She is partially hidden by the nude young man in front of her, with only her head, shoulders, and long gown visible.  She faces and looks to the left.

A flock of sheep graze on the grass between the hovering 
angels and Job's wife in the near middle-distance.
A hill or distant mountain is pictured above the sheep who graze between the hovering angels and Job's wife.
In the sky behind Job and his family are white wisps of clouds.
Job, his wife, and four members of his family sit on an odd bench-like seat with a dog lying under it.
A dog, lying prone and facing left, sleeps beneath the bench on which Job's children sit.
Two trees bearing leaves appear in the middle distance right of Job.  Both trees have vines, bearing leaves and clusters of grapes, entwined around the trunk.

Cloud bands, left and right, define the interior spaces of the upper part of the composition.  The clouds on the left extend 
downward to the area between the left margin and the hovering angels left of Job and his family; there are also clouds behind Satan's right foot.

God, enthroned, sits at the top.  Radiance and beams of light surround his head and upper body; his hair and beard are long.  His 
bare right foot appears beneath the hem of his gown.  He holds (with his 
left hand) an open book on his lap; he points downward with his right 
hand and extended index finger.
Beams of light extend from the radiant area around God's head and upper body.

God sits, enthroned, on a chair or seat, apparently made 
of stone.  It is raised on what appears to be a plinth, perhaps with at least one step.

Four nude angels hover to the left of God.  The upper-most angel faces right and slightly down; his posture suggests that he may be bowing.  
We see only the side and back of his head and his torso; his hair is long.

Four nude angels hover to the left of God.  The angel second 
from the top faces right and slightly down.  His hair appears to be short; he may be bowing.

Four nude angels hover to the left of God.  The third angel from the top faces right and 
slightly down, with his body facing partially forward.  His hair is short and curly.  His arms are extended horizontally towards the right.  
His posture suggests that he is bowing before God, and has just offered, with the fingers of his left hand spread apart, a book towards which he appears to be looking.  His legs are together.  His genitals are clearly visible.
Four angels hover to the left of God.  A closed book appears just right of the extended hands of the angel third from the top.

Four nude angels hover to the left of God.  The lower-most angel is nude and faces to the right.  
His body is turned away from the viewer, and twists slightly to the right; his right leg, which is extended backward, crosses behind his left at the knee.  
He has short, curly hair and holds an open book in his right hand.

Four nude angels hover to the left of God.  The lower-most 
angel is nude and faces to the right.  He holds a book showing several separated leaves.  The cover has clasps hanging down on both sides.

We see the head of Job's wife just below Satan's extended left arm.  She faces forward and to the right; her mouth 
is open and her long hair merges with the surrounding flames.

Satan hovers in flames in the middle.  He is nude except for a flame covering his genitals.  His arms are raised vertically with the fingers of 
both hands spread apart.  His mouth is open and he may be speaking.  His bare feet are prominent.

We see the head of Job just below Satan's extended right 
arm.  His long hair and beard merge with the surrounding 
flames.

Satan hovers before flames in the middle of the plate,
with one tongue of fire extending over his right thigh.  The 
faces of Job and his wife appear within the flames.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan.  We see only the head and back of the upper-most figure.  
Like his companions, he may be nude; his hair is short and curly.  He faces down and to the left and 
may be bowing before God.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan.  We see only the head, most of the face, and part of the body of 
the second figure from the top.  This figure, which appears to be nude and has fairly long hair, faces 
down and to the left as if bowing before God.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan.  The third figure from the top faces down and to the left, 
with his head raised and his lower body turned toward the viewer; he may be bowing before God.  He is nude and has curly hair of medium length.  His left leg is slightly bent 
at the knee, and his bare feet are prominent.  He reaches forward to the left and gestures with both hands toward a scroll. He may have placed the scroll before God's throne.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan.  The lowest two in the group are clustered together, with the rear-most figure, a (gowned?) 
male half covered by his companion.  He faces forward and to the left, but his upper body must be twisted slightly to the right, given that his arms are extended 
horizontally to the right, with the palms raised vertically.  His hair is long and perhaps curly; his legs are extended to the right and bent at the knees.  He looks toward Satan.

Five angels hover right of God and Satan.  The lowest 
two in the group are clustered together.  The front-most figure faces forward and to the left, with his upper body twisted at the waist.  
He is nude, and his hair is short and curly.  His legs are extended to the right and both are slightly bent at the knee.  
His left arm is bent across his body, and the right arm is bent upward.  He holds a scroll in both hands.

l.#text: Our Father which art in Heavn

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job, his wife, and his sons and daughters sit and kneel in 
attitudes of prayer before a large, central tree (perhaps an oak).  Job 
and his wife have open books (perhaps Bibles) on their laps; all seven 
sons hold shepherd's crooks.  The son farthest to the right also has a 
harp; a larger harp, a mandolin (or some such stringed instrument), a 
tambourine, and four horned instruments hang in the tree above the heads 
of Job and his wife.  A musical horn dangles by the side of the son 
farthest to the left.  Seven sheep, and what may be a sheepdog, lie in 
the grassy foreground.  Just behind the human figures is a large flock of sheep, 
visible left and right; behind the sheep are (from left to right) a clump of trees, 
a Gothic building (probably a church), an additional structure on the far left, and four tents.  Above the 
background hills and mountains are a radiant sun (left) that may be rising or setting, a star or planet, and a crescent moon (right).

p.#text: The inscription, taken from the Lord's Prayer (Matthew 6:9 and Luke 11:2), appears on the disc of the sun upper left.

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job's wife sits on the left side of the central tree, her 
hands together in prayer.  She is gowned and faces forward, but with her head turned slightly to the right and eyes raised; an open book (possibly a Bible) rests on her lap.

Job sits among his family on the right side of the central 
tree.  He has long hair, a beard and wears a gown, and faces forward with his head turned slightly to the left. His eyes are raised.  He holds 
an open book in his lap.  Like most of the other figures in the scene, Job may be praying.

On the far left of the group of figures is one of Job's 
sons.  He kneels while holding a shepherd's crook. Like most of the 
other figures in the scene, he may be praying.  A small musical horn 
dangles at his right thigh.  He wears a long gown and his hair is short 
and curly.  He faces half-way between forward and to the right, 
with his head lowered slightly. His bare right foot, and the bare heel 
of his left foot, are pictured.

The figure second from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels 
and prays, palms together.  He is gowned and faces half-way between 
forward and to the right.  His hair is long and a little curly; he 
holds a shepherd's crook under his left arm.  His head is raised 
slightly.

The figure third from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels 
and prays, hands clasped together.  He is gowned and faces half-way 
between forward and to the right.  He is bearded and his hair is long.  
Like his brother to the left, he is holding a shepherd's crook under his left arm.

We see only the face and part of the upper chest of Job's son fourth from the left.  He is probably kneeling, like his brothers, and may be praying.  He faces half-way between forward and to the right, with his head slightly lowered. The top of a shepherd's crook is visible above his head.

One of Job's daughters kneels in prayer between the group 
of four brothers on the left and Job's wife.  She wears a long gown; her hair is long and may in part be drawn back into a bun.  Her body faces to the right, and her head is turned slightly down.   Her bare feet 
are prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels between her parents in the 
center of the design.  Like her sister to the left, she may be praying.  
She is gowned and has long hair.  We see her from behind; her bare feet are 
prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels just to the right of Job and 
left of the group of three son's on the right.  Like her sisters, she 
may be praying.  She is gowned and has her arms crossed over her chest with the fingers of her right hand spread apart slightly.  She faces left and her head is tilted slightly down.  Her long(?) hair is gathered into a bun; her bare left foot is 
prominent.

One of Job's sons kneels in prayer, palms together, far 
right in the group of figures.  He is gowned; his hair is short and 
curly.  He holds a shepherd's crook, apparently between his bent arms; a 
lyre dangles below his left arm.  He faces to the left and his bare left 
foot is prominent.

One of Job's sons kneels in prayer, hands clasped 
together, second from the right in the group of figures.  He is gowned, 
bearded, and his hair is short and curly.  He faces half-way between 
forward and to the left and holds his shepherd's crook under his right 
arm.

One of Job's sons kneels third from the right in the group 
of figures.  He is gowned, bearded, and has short, curly hair.  Like his 
brothers to the right, he may be praying.  He faces half-way between 
forward and to the left and holds his shepherd's crook with both 
hands.

The group of foreground animals includes (left to right), a ram, four sheep, 
a dog with its muzzle resting on the hindquarters of a sheep apparently facing left, a ram, and perhaps the 
back of a fifth sheep.  All are lying prone; the dog, the sheep below his head, and both 
rams have their eyes closed and may be sleeping.  The rams display looped and spiral-like horns.

A small mound of earth appears below the central tree and 
kneeling figures.

The foreground landscape would appear to be covered with 
tufts of grass, particularly prominent below the sheep.

The upper center of the composition is anchored by a large 
and leafy tree, probably an oak.

A large flock of sheep is pictured in the middle distance 
on the left side of the composition.  They are all standing, some with 
heads down to eat the grass.

A large flock of sheep is pictured in the middle distance 
on the right side of the composition.  The front-most sheep is lying prone.  
Second from the front is a ram with twisted, spiral-like horns.

A small clump of leafy trees appears in the background 
near the left margin of the design and the large gothic 
building.

A large Gothic building, perhaps a church, appears in the 
background on the left.  It is decorated with towers, spires, and 
a central pointed arch that probably represents a doorway. 
The structure on the far left, with one archway and several spires, may be a separate building. 
The buildings are probably made of stone.

Two tents appear in the middle distance just right of the large tree. 
Another group of two tents appears far right under the crescent moon.

A cluster of leafy plants, probably bushes or small trees, 
appears between the sheep and the tents 
along the right margin.

A line of hills, with a larger mountain on the right, 
define the horizon.

A rising or setting sun bears a fragmented inscription of the Lord's Prayer inside its arc.  
Its radiance forms beams of light.
A few words from the Lord's Prayer are inscribed within the sun: "Our Father which art in Heavn / Hallowed by thy Name / Thy Will Be".

A crescent moon 
appears in the sky 
on the right.

A star or planet (possibly Venus, given the rising or 
setting sun far left) appears above the mountain peak left of the 
crescent moon.

A group of seven musical instruments hang in the tree 
above the heads of Job and his wife.  They are, from left to right, a 
horn with a looped, spiral-like body, a tambourine, a mandolin (or some 
such stringed instrument), a large triangular harp, two horns, and a 
trumpet.

note.#text: Lines 1-2 are lightly written in pencil within the small portion of the sun's disc appearing just above the distant mountains on the left.
Very probably a fragmentary transcription of words from the Lord's Prayer, "in Heaven, hallowed be thy Name."

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job, his wife, and his sons and daughters sit and kneel in 
attitudes of prayer before a large, central tree (perhaps an oak).  Job 
and his wife have open books (perhaps Bibles) on their laps; all seven 
sons hold shepherd's crooks.  The son farthest to the right also has a 
harp; a larger harp, a mandolin (or some such stringed instrument), a 
tambourine, and four horned instruments hang in the tree above the heads 
of Job and his wife.  A musical horn dangles by the side of the son 
farthest to the left.  Seven sheep, and what may be a sheepdog, lie in 
the grassy foreground.  Just behind the human figures is a large flock of sheep, 
visible left and right; behind the sheep are (from left to right) a clump of trees, 
a Gothic building (probably a church), an additional structure on the far left, and four tents.  Above the 
background hills and mountains are a radiant sun (left) that may be rising or setting, a star or planet, and a crescent moon (right).

Job sits among his family on the right side of the central 
tree.  He has long hair, a beard and wears a gown, and faces forward with his head turned slightly to the left. His eyes are raised.  He holds 
an open book in his lap.  Like most of the other figures in the scene, Job may be praying.

On the far left of the group of figures is one of Job's 
sons.  He kneels while holding a shepherd's crook. Like most of the 
other figures in the scene, he may be praying.  A small musical horn 
dangles at his right thigh.  He wears a long gown and his hair is short 
and curly.  He faces half-way between forward and to the right, 
with his head lowered slightly. His bare right foot, and the bare heel 
of his left foot, are pictured.

The figure second from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels 
and prays, palms together.  He is gowned and faces half-way between 
forward and to the right.  His hair is short and a little curly; he 
holds a shepherd's crook under his left arm.  His head is raised 
slightly.

The figure third from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels 
and prays, hands clasped together.  He is gowned and faces half-way 
between forward and to the right.  He is bearded and his hair is long.  
Like his brother to the left, he is holding a shepherd's crook under his left arm.

We see only the face and part of the upper chest of Job's son fourth from the left.  
He is probably kneeling, like his brothers, and may be praying.  
He faces half-way between forward and to the right, with his head slightly lowered. The top of a shepherd's crook is visible above his head.

One of Job's daughters kneels in prayer between the group 
of four brothers on the left and Job's wife.  She wears a long gown; her hair is short and curly.  
Her body faces to the right, and her head is turned slightly down.   Her bare feet 
are prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels between her parents in the 
center of the design.  Like her sister to the left, she may be praying.  
She is gowned and has long hair.  We see her from behind; her bare feet are 
prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels just to the right of Job and 
left of the group of three sons on the right.  Like her sisters, she 
may be praying.  She is gowned and has her arms crossed over her chest, and the fingers of her right hand are spread apart slightly.  
She faces left with her head tilted slightly down.  Her long(?) hair is gathered into a bun; her bare left foot is 
prominent.

One of Job's sons kneels in prayer, palms together, far 
right in the group of figures.  He is gowned; his hair is short and 
curly.  He holds a shepherd's crook, apparently between his bent arms; a 
lyre dangles below his left arm.  He faces to the left and his bare left 
foot is prominent.

One of Job's sons kneels in prayer, hands clasped 
together, second from the right in the group of figures.  He is gowned, 
bearded, and his hair is short and curly.  He faces half-way between 
forward and to the left and holds his shepherd's crook under his right 
arm.

One of Job's sons kneels third from the right in the group 
of figures.  He is gowned, bearded, and has short, curly hair.  Like his 
brothers to the right, he may be praying.  He faces half-way between 
forward and to the left and holds his shepherd's crook with both 
hands.

The group of foreground animals includes (left to right), a ram, four sheep, 
a dog with its muzzle resting on the hindquarters of a sheep apparently facing left, a ram, and perhaps the 
back of a fifth sheep.  All are lying prone; the dog, the sheep below his head, and both 
rams have their eyes closed and may be sleeping.  The rams display looped and spiral-like horns.

A small mound of earth appears below the central tree and 
kneeling figures.

The foreground landscape would appear to be covered with 
tufts of grass, particularly prominent below the sheep.

The upper center of the composition is anchored by a large 
and leafy tree, probably an oak.

A large flock of sheep is pictured in the middle distance 
on the left side of the composition.  They are all standing, some with 
heads down to eat the grass.

A large flock of sheep is pictured in the middle distance 
on the right side of the composition.  The front-most sheep is lying prone.  
Second from the front is a ram with twisted, spiral-like horns.

A small clump of leafy trees appears in the background 
near the left margin of the design and the large gothic 
building.

A large Gothic building, perhaps a church, appears in the 
background on the left.  It is decorated with a tower, spires, and 
a central pointed arch that probably represents a doorway. 
The structure on the far left, with one archway and several spires, may be a separate building. 
The buildings are probably made of stone.

Two tents appear in the middle distance just right of the large tree. 
Another group of tents appears far right under the crescent moon.

A cluster of leafy plants, probably bushes or small trees, 
appears between the sheep and the tents 
along the right margin.

A line of hills, with a larger mountain on the right, 
define the horizon.

A rising or setting sun bears a fragmented inscription of the Lord's Prayer inside its arc.  
Its radiance forms beams of light.
A few words from the Lord's Prayer are inscribed within the sun: "Our Father which art / in Hea ... Name".

A crescent moon 
appears in the sky 
on the right.

A star or planet (possibly Venus, given the rising or 
setting sun far left) appears above the mountain peak left of the 
crescent moon.

A group of seven musical instruments hang in the tree 
above the heads of Job and his wife.  They are, from left to right, a 
horn with a looped, spiral-like body, a tambourine, a mandolin (or some 
such stringed instrument), a large triangular harp, two horns, and a 
trumpet.

The scene shows the destruction of Job's family 
at the hands of Satan.  The background is filled with dark flames and, 
at the top, bolts of lightning.  Below are falling architectural 
elements, including at least two columns and steps.  On and about these 
steps are, just above the bottom margin, a gowned female lying supine, 
perhaps dead, with a lyre at her left hand and a tambourine at her feet.  
In the near foreground on the right is a nude male in an upside-down 
cruciform posture, with large plates and vessels below him.  Another 
upside-down figure hangs just left of the lower right margin.  The other 
figures in the lower half of the design are, from left to right, a group 
of three females(?) clearly terrified (we see only their heads and 
gesturing arms and hands); two females reaching (for succor?) toward the 
male to the right; a large central nude male (whose posture, reversed, 
suggests that of Laocoön in the famous classical sculpture) with a child 
on his left shoulder; and a group of five figures below the central 
male, all with upraised arms.  Above, Satan grins maniacally as he rains fire on his victims from his outstretched hands.  He is half-kneeling, legs crossed, on stony blocks; his bat-like 
wings dominate the top of the design.  Radiance and bolts of lightning frame his head with a parodic halo.

title: Job's Sons and Daughters Overwhelmed by Satan

illusobjdesc.#text: The background is filled with blue and gray flames.
Bolts of lightning flash from behind Satan's head and body.  Stormy clouds, or, perhaps, smoke surround him.

Satan, in the top third of the design, half-kneels on a 
large block, probably of stone.  Another such block appears just right 
of his right foot.  These are probably broken pieces of the house of 
Job's eldest son.  They may be falling on the figures 
below.

Two falling columns, probably made of stone, indicate the 
destruction of the house of Job's eldest son.  The upper-most column has 
a simple classical capital.  The block under the lower column fragment, 
and just left of the right margin, may also be a 
broken column.

The figures in the lower margins are 
displayed on or about a series of (stone?) steps rising from left to 
right.  In the lower right corner is what may be another step, or perhaps stone block, visible just right of the upside-down figure in the foreground.

At least two large plates or platters, one goblet, and a vase or bottle fill the space beneath the outstretched arms of the 
upside-down figure in the lower right corner.

A tambourine rests beneath the feet of the supine woman 
just above the bottom margin.  A lyre rests under her left hand.

A gowned young woman—a member of Job's family now being destroyed—lies supine just above the lower margin.  Her long, curly hair is spread out on the ground; her legs, slightly bent at the knees, are together and her arms are at her sides.  A tambourine rests beneath her left(?) foot, and a lyre lies below her left hand.  Her head is bent back and her eyes are closed; she may be dead.

A youthful male with curly hair hangs upside down in the lower right corner.  
His eyes are closed; he appears to be dead.  His arms, raised at 135 degrees relative to his body, suggest a cruciform position.  His body is twisted, and his legs are bent to the left.

A youthful figure, most likely male, hangs upside down in the lower right corner, just to the right of the more prominent upside-down figure. 
He appears to be nude and facing up.  The back of his head is visible as it rests on the ground.  He may be dead.

A group of three females(?) in the middle distance are the left-most figures in the composition.  
We see only their heads, arms, and upper bodies.  The figure farthest to the left is of indeterminate gender and appears to be gowned.  
She(?) twists her head up, back, and to the right.  Her right arm is bent over her head; her left arm is bent, extended across her body, and raised at 135 degrees.  
Her hair is probably short.

A group of three females(?) in the middle distance are the left-most figures in the composition.  We see only their heads, 
arms, and upper bodies.  The figure second from the left faces forward and right with her head up and eyes raised; she is wearing a gown, and has long, curly hair.  
Her mouth is open, and her facial expression suggests fear.  The position of her right shoulder suggests that she is reaching upwards toward the climbing male figure.

A group of three figures in the middle distance are the left-most figures in the composition. The figure third from the left is of indeterminate gender. 
He(?) faces forward and right with his head up and eyes raised. His hair is curly, and his mouth is open in an expression of pain or terror.

Two young, long-haired, and gowned females are pictured immediately to the left of the central male figure.  
They both raise their arms at 135 degrees toward the male, who appears to be helping at least the front-most female to rise and climb the steps.  The fingers of the woman in the background are spread. The front-most figure in this group 
faces to the right, with her head bent back.  Her right leg is drawn up and bent beneath her as she kneels on a step; her left leg is extended backward and bent at the knee.  
Her right arm is raised; with her right hand she grasps the arm of the central male, who grasps her arm in turn.  A tail of drapery from her gown curls behind her left(?) foot.

Two young, long-haired, and gowned females are pictured immediately to the left of the central male figure.  They both raise their arms at 135 degrees toward the male, who appears to be helping at least the front-most female rise and climb the steps.  The female figure just to the right of and above 
the front-most female reaches upward with her palms raised vertically and her fingers spread.  She is gowned, and at least one of her legs is bent at the knee as she climbs upward; her (right?) knee and foot are visible behind the central male's left leg.  She faces upward and to the right with head bent back and her eyes raised.  Her expression suggests pain or terror.

A female figure, with right arm raised at 135 degrees, palm vertical, and fingers clearly visible, appears beneath the 
                     central male's left knee.  We see her face, raised right arm and hand, and possibly part of her back and upper right leg, the leg perhaps covered with drapery.  Her eyes are closed as she faces to the right, and her hair appears to be long.

A group of five figures is pictured below the central male figure.  They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male.  
The leftmost figure, who appears to be male and nude, is seen from behind with his head turned upward and body slightly twisted.  His head is bent back, and his arms are raised with palms vertical and fingers spread.

A group of five figures is pictured below the central male figure.  They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male.  The figure second from the left, who appears to be nude and female, is seen from behind, her head turned upward and her body twisted.

A group of five figures is pictured below the central male figure.  They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male.  
The (male?) figure third from the left is seen from behind with his arms raised vertically to grasp the uppermost step with his right hand and the step immediately below with his left.   
He has curly hair, and appears to be partly nude, with a gown covering his lower body.

A group of five figures is pictured below the central male figure.  They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male.  
The (male?) figure second to the left of the upside-down male is seen from behind with his arms raised vertically to grasp the uppermost step.

A group of five figures is pictured below the central male figure.  They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The right-most figure in this group appears to be nude and male. We see him from behind; his head is bent back and faces to the left.  His arms are raised vertically above his head with both palms out and up.  He has curly hair, his mouth is open, and his expression suggests pain, terror, or fear.

A youthful and muscular male dominates the center in the 
lower half portion.  He stands and faces forward, with his 
left leg bent sharply at the knee to position his foot on a raised step.  
His right leg is extended to the left.  He may be attempting to climb 
the steps to the right.  His upper body and neck are twisted to the left; he may be looking at the females to the left.  His posture echoes 
that of Laocoön, reversed, in the famous classical sculpture group.  He 
is nude except for a bit of drapery that extends along the right side of 
his chest and covers his genitals.  He extends his right arm downward to 
grasp the upper arm of the female to the left.  His left arm is bent 
upward to hold a child sitting on his left shoulder.  The fingers of his left hand are spread apart.  His hair 
is short and curly.

A young (female?) child or infant with curly hair sits on the shoulder of the central male figure.  We see her from behind, with her 
head twisted to the left so that she faces us.  Her mouth is slightly open, possibly in an expression of fear.  Her extended left arm reaches to the left; she appears 
to be grasping the hair of the male with her left hand. The child appears to be wearing a gown with drapery.

A nude Satan with bat-like wings 
dominates the top portion.  He squats, crouches, or half-kneels, with legs sharply bent, on some stony blocks, his legs crossed 
just above the ankles.  His arms are extended outward from his body at 45 degrees, with his fingers spread apart, his palms facing down, and flames issuing 
from his hands and fingertips.  His hair is short and curly.  He faces forward with eyes closed, or possibly cast sharply downward.  His head is twisted down and to the right. 
Lightning and radiance flash from behind and surrounds his head and body in a manner suggestive of a parodic halo. 
A slight, and no doubt sardonic, smile indicates his pleasure in destruction.

The subject of this painting is not biblical but might derive from two passages in the Apocrypha, I Timothy 2:5-6 and 1 John 2:1. Jesus stands in the middle of this design, facing forward, but looking slightly to the right. He wears a gown, with a belt at the chest, and has long, curly hair and a beard. An aura of light around his head suggests a halo. He bends his right knee and raises both arms horizontally, with his right palm down and his left palm up. This posture recalls his crucifixion. He is looking at God the Father to his right. To the right of Jesus sits God the Father in his role as a judge, portrayed as an old man with long hair and a beard. He wears a gown and sits, facing left, and presumably looking at Jesus. His left arm is bent and rests on the arm of the chair or throne in which he sits. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees and he holds in his right hand a scepter with a fleur-de-lis finial. His left foot is visible from beneath the hem of his gown. Only the left arm of the throne or chair in which God sits is visible. An angel kneels below God the Father, facing left and hunched over so that he looks down. He wears a gown and has wings and long, slightly curly hair. His arms are bent and his hands are held together as if in prayer or supplication. To the left of Jesus stands Mary Magdalene, facing right and forward. She bends forward into a bow. She wears a gown and has long, curly hair. Her right leg is bent and her right foot is on tiptoe, suggesting that she is walking to the right or about to kneel. Her arms are raised, with her hands folded together on her chest—a gesture that suggests supplication. Surrounding Mary Magdalene are six child-like angels or cherubs, two to the left, one above her, and three to the right. The leftmost angel is seen from behind, though he twists his head to face left. He wears a gown and has wings and long, curly hair. His right leg is extended backward. The middle angel to the left of Mary Magdalene faces right and hovers in mid-air. He wears a gown and has wings. His right arm is bent upward. He may cover his face with his hands or arms, since it is not visible. He may be praying. The angel above Mary Magdalene faces right and down, as though bowing. He wears a gown and has wings and long, curly hair. His arms are bent upward and his mouth may be slightly open. He also floats or hovers in mid-air. The lower angel to the right of Mary Magdalene may hover or stand. This angel appears to be a female child. She faces forward, with her arms raised and her hands together as if in prayer or supplication. She appears to look up at Mary Magdalene. She wears a gown and has wings as well as long hair. The middle angel to the right of Mary Magdalene faces away, though he(?) looks up at Mary Magdalene. His mouth may be open and thus he may be speaking. The wings and long hair of this angel are visible. The upper angel to the right of Mary Magdalene faces forward and may look at Mary Magdalene. Its mouth may be slightly open. This angel's curly hair is visible, but little else besides its head and upper body. This scene takes place in heaven, but the background is dark with the exception of Jesus's aura. Flames wrap from God the Father's feet to the left and above his head along the top margin of the design, and extend to the end of Jesus's right hand.

p.#text: The painting was restored by John Hell in 1950.

title: "Christ the Mediator": Christ Pleading Before the Father for St. Mary Magdalene

illusobjdesc.#text: Jesus stands in the middle of this design, facing forward, but looking slightly to the right. He wears a gown, with a belt at the chest, and has long, curly hair and a beard. An aura of light around his head suggests a halo. He bends his right knee and raises both arms horizontally, with his right palm down and his left palm up. This posture recalls his crucifixion. He is looking at God the Father to his right.

To the right of Jesus sits God the Father in his role as a judge, portrayed as an old man with long hair and a beard. He wears a gown and sits, facing left, and presumably looking at Jesus. His left arm is bent and rests on the arm of the chair or throne in which he sits. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees and he holds in his right hand a scepter with a fleur-de-lis finial. His left foot is visible from beneath the hem of his gown.
Only the left arm of the throne or chair in which God the Father sits is visible.

An angel kneels below God the Father, facing left and hunched over so that he looks down. He wears a gown and has wings and long, slightly curly hair. His arms are bent and his hands are held together as if in prayer or supplication.

To the left of Jesus stands Mary Magdalene, facing right and forward. She bends forward into a bow. She wears a gown and has long, curly hair. Her right leg is bent and her right foot is on tiptoe, suggesting that she is walking to the right or about to kneel. Her arms are raised, with her hands folded together on her chest—a gesture that suggests supplication.

Surrounding Mary Magdalene are six child-like angels or cherubs, two to the left, one above, and three to the right. The leftmost angel is seen from behind, though he twists his head to face left. He wears a gown and has wings and long, curly hair. His right leg is extended backward.

The upper angel to the left of Mary Magdalene faces right and hovers in mid-air. He wears a gown and has wings. His right arm is bent upward. He may cover his face with his hands or arms, since it is not visible. He may be praying.

The angel above Mary Magdalene faces right and down, as though bowing. He wears a gown and has wings and long, curly hair. His arms are bent upward and his mouth may be slightly open. He floats or hovers in mid-air.

Surrounding Mary Magdalene are six child-like angels or cherubs, two to the left, one above, and three to the right. The lower angel to the right of Mary Magdalene may hover or stand. This angel appears to be a female child. She faces forward, with her arms raised and her hands together as if in prayer or supplication. She appears to look up at Mary Magdalene. She wears a gown and has wings as well as long hair.

Surrounding Mary Magdalene are six child-like angels or cherubs, two to the left, one above, and three to the right. The middle angel to the right of Mary Magdalene faces away, though he(?) looks up at Mary Magdalene. His mouth may be open and thus he may be speaking. The wings and long hair of this angel are visible.

Surrounding Mary Magdalene are six child-like angels or cherubs, two to the left, one above, and three to her right. The upper angel to the right of Mary Magdalene faces forward and may look at Mary Magdalene. His(?) mouth may be slightly open. This angel's curly hair is visible, but little else besides its head and upper body.
This scene takes place in Heaven, but the background is dark with the exception of Jesus's aura.
Flames wrap from God the Father's feet to the left and above his head along the top margin of the design, and extend to the end of Jesus's right hand.

note.#text: This number, written in pencil and preceded by a check mark, corresponds with the inscribed number on the engraving of the same design (object 5 of Blake's engravings for ).  The number is probably not in Blake's hand, but it may have been written by John Linnell or a member of his family.

illusobjdesc.#text:
The design shows the destruction of Job's family at the hands of Satan.  The background is filled with dark flames and, 
                  at the top, 
                  bolts of lightning.  Below are falling architectural elements, including at least two columns, and steps.  On and about these steps are, just above 
                  the bottom margin, a gowned female lying supine, perhaps dead, with a lyre under her left hand and a tambourine under her feet.  In the near foreground 
                  on the right is a nude male in an upside-down cruciform posture.  There may be a platter under his left hand, as in the engraving.  
                  The other figures in the lower half of the design are, from left to right, a group of three figures clearly terrified (we see only their heads and 
                  gesturing arms and hands); two females reaching (for succor?) toward the male to the right; a large central nude male (whose posture, reversed, 
                  suggests that of Laocoön in the famous classical sculpture) with a child on his left shoulder; and a group of four figures below the central male, 
                  all with upraised arms.  A few lines hint at a second upside-down figure just within the lower right margin.  Above, Satan grins maniacally as he rains fire on his victims from his outstretched hands.  He is half-kneeling, 
                  legs crossed, on a stony block; his bat-like wings dominate the top of the design.  Radiance and bolts of lightning frame his head.

p.#text:
A preliminary border design, possibly including reclining human figures lower left and right, is sketched in pencil on all four sides of the 
                  design.  The verso of this leaf (Butlin 557.12) is blank.

title: Study for Plate 3: Job's Sons and Daughters Overwhelmed by Satan

illusobjdesc.#text: The background of the design is filled with flames.
Bolts of lightning flash from behind Satan's head and body, and along his right side.  Clouds of smoke, or perhaps storm clouds, surround him.

Satan, in the top third of the design, half-kneels on a large block, probably of stone.  Another such block appears just 
                     right of his 
                     right foot.  These are probably broken pieces of the house of Job's eldest son.  They may be falling on the figures below.

Two falling columns (or two pieces of the same column), probably made of stone, indicate the destruction of the house of Job's eldest son.  The upper-most 
                     column has 
                     a simple classical capital.

The figures in the lower part of the design are displayed on or about a series of (stone?) steps rising from 
                     left to right.

A tambourine rests beneath the feet of the supine woman just above the bottom margin of the design.  
                  A lyre rests beneath her left hand.

A gowned young woman—a member of Job's family now being destroyed—lies supine just above the lower margin of the 
                     design.  
                     Her long, curly hair is spread out on the ground, her visible leg is slightly bent at the knees, and her left arm is at her side.  
                     A tambourine rests beneath her bare left foot; a lyre rests below her left hand. Her head is bent back; she may be dead.

A male hangs upside down in the lower right corner of the design.  His eyes are closed(?); he appears to be 
                     dead.  
                     His arms, raised at 135 degrees relative to his body, suggest a cruciform position.  His body is twisted slightly to the left, and his legs, 
                     which may be crossed, are bent over the step.
A few lines, including a circle, just within the lower right margin of the design may be the beginnings of a second upside-down figure, as in the engraving.

A group of three figures (probably females, as in the engraving) in the middle distance are left-most in the composition.  
                     We see only their heads, arms, and 
                     upper bodies.  
                     The figure farthest to the left twists her head up, back, and to the right.  Her right arm is bent over her 
                     head; her left arm is bent, extended across her body, and raised at 135 degrees.  Her palms are vertical; the palm of her right hand faces 
                     out, and her fingers may be spread.

A group of three figures (probably females, as in the engraving) in the middle distance are left-most in the composition.  We see only their heads, arms, and 
                     upper bodies.  The figure second from the left faces forward and right with her head up.  She may have long hair.

A group of three figures (probably females, as in the engraving) in the middle distance are left-most in the composition.  We see only their heads, arms, and 
                     upper bodies.      
                     The figure third from the left faces forward and right with her head up. Her mouth 
                     may be open in an expression of pain or terror.

Two young, long-haired, and gowned females are pictured immediately to the left of the central male figure.  
                     They both raise their arms at 
                     135 degrees with fingers spread toward the male, who appears to be helping them to rise and climb the steps.    
                     The front-most figure in this group faces to the right with her head bent back and her mouth open in an expression of pain or fear.  Her 
                     right leg is drawn up and bent beneath her as she kneels on a 
                     step; her left leg is extended backward and bent at the knee.  
                     Her right arm is raised and held at its elbow by he central male.  Her feet are 
                     prominent beyond her gown’s hem.  Both feet may be on tiptoe.

Two young, long-haired, and gowned females are pictured immediately to the left of the central male figure.  
                     They both raise their arms at 135 degrees toward the male, 
                     who appears to be helping them to rise and climb the steps.  The female figure just to the right of and above 
                     the kneeling female in the foreground reaches upward with her palms raised vertically and her fingers spread.  
                     Her left(?) leg is bent at the knee as she climbs upward; her right(?) leg is extended backwards.  She faces upward and to the right with her head bent back and her mouth open.  
                     Her expression suggests pain or terror.

A figure (probably female, as in the engraving), with her left arm raised vertically, appears between the central 
                     male's right leg and the steps just to the right.  We see only her head, 
                     upper body, and raised arm and hand.  She faces forward.  
                     Her gesture suggests some mixture of pain and terror.

A group of four figures (probably female, as in the engraving) is pictured below the left foot of the central male figure.  They reach upward, as though 
                     seeking aid from the male.  
                     The leftmost figure is probably seen from behind, with its arms raised vertically.  It may be grasping the stone steps, perhaps in order to climb upward.

A group of four figures (probably female, as in the engraving) is pictured below the central male figure.  They reach upward, as though seeking aid from 
                     the male.  The 
                     figure second from the left, who appears to be nude, is seen from behind.  The figure's head is turned upward and to the right, and 
                     her body is 
                     twisted.  Her hair may be long.  She may be grasping the stone steps with her hands, perhaps in order to climb upward.

A group of four figures (probably female, as in the engraving) is pictured below the central male figure.  They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the 
                     male.  The 
                     figure third from the left is seen from behind with her arms raised vertically to grasp the two uppermost steps.  
                  She may trying to climb upward.

A group of four figures (probably female, as in the engraving) is pictured below the central male figure.  They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the 
                     male.  
                     The figure left of the upside-down male faces forward, her head tilted back and with her arms raised vertically and her hands crossed 
                     over her head.

A youthful and muscular male dominates the center of the 
                     lower half of the design.  He stands and faces forward, with his 
                     left leg bent sharply at the knee to position his foot on a raised step.  
                     His right leg is extended to the left.  Both feet are on tiptoe.  He may be attempting to climb 
                     the steps to the right.  His upper body and neck are twisted to the left; he may be looking at the females to the left.  His posture echoes 
                     that of Laocoön, reversed, in the famous classical sculpture group.  He 
                     is nude except for a bit of drapery that extends along the right side of 
                     his chest and covers his genitals.  He extends his right arm downward to 
                     grasp the elbow of the female to the left.  His left arm is bent 
                     upward to hold a child sitting on his left shoulder.  The fingers of his left hand may be spread apart.  His hair 
                     is short and curly.

A young child or infant with short hair sits on the shoulder of the central male figure.  We see the child from 
                     behind, with its 
                     head twisted sharply to the left so that it faces us.  The child's mouth is slightly open, possibly in an expression of fear.  The child's extended 
                     left arm reaches 
                     to the left, and appears to be grasping the hair of the male with the left hand.  The child appears to be wearing a diaphanous gown with drapery, which makes its buttocks prominent.  Its 
                     right leg dangles below the central male’s left bicep, making the bare right foot prominent.

A nude Satan with bat-like wings 
                     dominates the top of the design.  He squats, crouches, or half-kneels, with legs sharply bent, on some stony blocks, his left foot 
                     crossing over his right calf.  His arms are extended outward from his body at 45 degrees, with fingers spread apart and flames issuing from his hands 
                     and 
                     fingertips (palms facing down).  His hair is short and curly.  He faces forward, with his head twisted down and to the right. 
                     Lightning and radiance(?) flash around him.  A slight, and no doubt sardonic, smile indicates his pleasure in 
                     destruction.

Sharp lines indicative of lightening bolts dominate the top border design.  The curving lines in the left and right margins may indicate clouds or smoke, as in the engraving.  The border designs appear to reflect the sky behind Satan in the central sketch.
The wavy, sketchy lines in the lower marginal design might suggest a landscape of hills or mountains.  Curling lines left and right perhaps hint at clouds.

note.#text: The pencil inscriptions on the recto of this outer front cover leaf of the sketchbook are mostly trial efforts at a WB (William Blake) signature or monogram.  The exceptions are an Albrecht Durer monogram ("A" over "D"—see lines 3-4), perhaps inscribed as a model or precedent for the WB signatures, and the numerical calculations in lines 9-11 and 30-31.  Butlin 557.I states that all the inscriptions were "probably done by the Linnell family."  Their motivation for such an activity is unclear; one could understand their placing a single Blake signature on the cover to indicate the authorship of the drawings that follow, but why would anyone other than Blake practice a Blake signature over 30 times on the cover of a valuable sketchbook?  There is at least a slight chance that these inscriptions are by Blake.  The inscriptions on this recto of the outer front cover might have been written along with the similar inscriptions on the conjugate verso of the outer back cover (object 32) before the sheet was folded.
Lines 1-2 are inscribed within an almost-complete circle to form a monogram.
The "AD" monogram in lines 3-4, used by Albrecht Durer in many of his famous works, is inscribed within a square with a circular form attached to its top horizontal.
The first "W" is written sideways.  The "W.B." inscription, combined with "inv & sc" (line 5) within a semi-circle, forms a monogram.
The "B" is written sideways facing down.
The small letters of "in & sc." are written within the second "W" in line 9.  The first two letters may be "iv".  The ampersand is partly obscured by the second "W" in line 9.

The numbers in lines 9-11, with a line drawn between the numbers in lines 10-11, are a multiplication of 1000 by 100 to arrive at 100000 (line 11).  They appear to have been written with a sharper, perhaps harder, pencil than the other inscriptions on this leaf; they may be by a different hand.  See line 30 for another numerical calculation.
Line 8, combined with the second (and very large) "W" in line 9 and the second "B" in line 10, form an engraver's signature—"WB in[venit] & sc[ulpsit]."
This small inscription, enclosed within a semi-circle above "WB" in line 18 to form an engraver's monogram, is unclear.  Our reading of the ampersand and the following letter is conjectural.
The second "W" is written upside-down, with two diagonal lines drawn through its lower portion.
The final "W" is intertwined with the "B" below it, line 20.
The first "B" is very faint; the second "B" is conjectural.
The "WB" inscription is extremely faint.
In the first "WB" inscription, the letters are written over each other.  The second "W" is extremely faint; our reading is conjectural.  The final "B" is written sideways facing down.
The second "B" is very faint.
The final "B" is nested within the final "W" in line 28.

Our reading of the numbers in lines 30-31, written on a diagonal rising from left to right, is conjectural.  The numbers in line 30 are followed by a diagonal line, similarly rising from left to right.  This may be a numerical calculation, as in lines 9-11.
