note.#text: This list of Apostles, lines 1-12, is in Blake's hand.  It is probably based on the lists given in the Bible: Matthew 10, Mark 3, and Luke 6.
The final two letters of "Bartholomew" are unclear; our reading is conjectural.
The final "T" is incomplete.  Our reading is conjectural; Butlin 557.II suggests a number "7".
The final "J" is conjectural; Butlin 557.II suggests the number "8".
The inscription is unclear; our reading is conjectural.  Butlin 557.II suggests "10 Taddeus T".  According to Matthew 10:3, "Thaddus" was the surname of "Lebbus".
The letters are unclear; our reading is conjectural.

illusobjdesc.#text:
A leaf from Hayley’s Ballads, containing verses 29-31 of “Ballad the Third,” has a list of the twelve apostles’ names written and numbered by Blake in the upper 
                  left corner.  To the right of this list is a sketch of Job’s head and shoulders.  Job faces away from the viewer with his head bent back.  In the lower half of the leaf are indistinct pencil marks.

p.#text: This outer front cover is made from a leaf of  (1802), folded once through its short dimension.  The letterpress text is the bottom half of page 37.  The drawing is a study for plate 18 of the engravings, showing a back view of Job's head.  See object 24 for the preliminary drawing of the full composition on plate 18.

hi.#text: Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley. . .Drawn, Engraved, and Published, by William Blake

illusobjdesc.#text:
A sketch of Job facing away from the viewer appears in the upper center of the leaf.  His hair is represented by long and short pencil strokes.  His gown trails over 
                     what seems to be 
                     his shoulder.  A long horizontal line may indicate that his left arm is raised; a much shorter line below and to the right of his head suggests that his right arm is also raised.  He appears to 
                     have his head bent back; he may be looking upwards and slightly to the right.  
                     The distinguishing facial features that can be discerned are his forehead, nose, and right cheek.  There may be an outline of his mustache as it connects to adjacent lines near his face, 
                     which suggest a flowing beard.

note.#text: This line is curved.

l.#text: And my Servant Job shall pray for you
And the Lord turned the captivity of Job when he prayed for his Friends
London Published as the Act directs March 8: 1825 by Will Blake N3 Fountain Court Strand

note.#text: Lines 5-27 are inscribed as the text in the image of an opened book in the lower left corner. Lines 5-14 form the text of the book's left page; lines 15-27 form the text of the right page. Following the image of the book, all of the lines slant upwards from left to right.
The fragmentary word ("tha") at the end of the line may be a poorly-formed attempt at the word "them"; see the source of this inscription in Matthew 5:44.
The word ("the") at the end of the line may be a fragment of the word "them"; see the source of this inscription in Matthew 5:44.
The second word ("despitefull") is probably an incomplete rendering of "despitefully"; see the source of this inscription in Matthew 5:44.

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job stands, with his back to us, before a stone altar, 
above which rises a triangular or heart-shaped flame.  His cruciform 
posture, with arms extended a little above the horizontal, suggests a 
self-sacrifice.  Job's wife kneels on the left; his three friends kneel 
with heads bowed on the right.  An arching cloud band and a great burst 
of radiance fill the sky above a landscape of trees and distant 
mountains.

Job stands, with his back to us, before a stone altar, 
above which rises a heart-shaped flame.  His cruciform posture, with 
arms extended a little above the horizontal, suggests a self-sacrifice 
Job is giving to his God and perhaps a type of spiritual ecstasy.  He is 
gowned and bearded, with long hair.  The fingers of his extended hands 
(palms facing up and out) are spread apart.  His right leg is slightly 
bent and extended a bit behind him, with his right foot balanced on 
tiptoe.  His head is turned to the left and tilted upward.  His right 
foot and the flowing hem of his garment are prominent.

Job's wife kneels in prayer just left of her husband.  She 
is gowned and has exceptionally long hair.  She faces away and to the 
right.  Her arms are bent upward with her right hand near her face.  Her 
left hand is not pictured, but her posture and gestures suggest that her 
hands are together in prayer.

Job's three friends kneel lower right.  Like Job's wife, 
they may be praying.  Their postures are somewhat contracted as they 
bend forward.  We see them from behind, the soles of their feet visible 
beneath their gowns.  Given our identifications of the friends in object 
9 (the plate numbered 7), they are Bildad (the central figure) and Eliphaz 
and Zophar right and left of Bildad.  The representations of Eliphaz and 
Zophar are in this plate insufficient to discriminate between them.  
Bildad's hair is curly.

Job's three friends kneel lower right.  Like Job's wife, 
they may be praying.  Their postures are somewhat contracted as they 
bend forward.  We see them from behind, the soles of their feet visible 
beneath their gowns.  Given our identifications of the friends in object 
9 (the plate numbered 7), they are Bildad (the central figure) and Eliphaz 
and Zophar right and left of Bildad.  The representations of Eliphaz and 
Zophar are in this plate insufficient to discriminate between them.  
These two figures have long hair.
A large stone altar stands behind Job.

A large, triangular or heart-shaped flame rises from the 
altar behind Job.  This is probably a burning sacrifice Job is offering 
to his God.

Patches of grass grow on the ground below the figures.  
The ground (perhaps covered with vegetation) is higher on the right and 
left.  Leafy trees stand on the top of this rising 
ground.

The ground rises, in a way that suggests mounds or low 
hills, far right and left between the foreground and the trees in the 
middle distance.

A cloud band arches in the sky just above distant 
mountains.  Above the cloud is a great burst of radiant beams of 
light.

A cloud band arches through the upper border design.  
Short lines of radiance extend below the cloud on the left and 
right.

Cloud outlines decorate the middle of the left border.  
There may be a small cloud just beneath the feet of the front-most 
angel.

Cloud outlines decorate the middle of the right 
border.

Three angels hover near the top left corner of the inner 
framing lines.  Their gender is uncertain, although the outline of 
breasts on the left-most angel suggests a female.  The front-most angel 
holds two horns or pipes (musical instruments).  Although they do not 
touch his lips, he may be playing these pipes.  He is gowned, winged, 
and faces forward, with his head turned slightly downward.  His hair is 
long.  His legs are together and his mouth may be slightly open.  His 
left arm is bent horizontally across his chest; his bare feet are 
prominent.

The front-most angel in the group of three holds two horns 
or musical pipes.

Three angels hover near the top left corner of the inner 
framing lines.  Their gender is uncertain, although the outline of 
breasts on the left-most angel suggests a female.  The middle figure 
faces forward, with head twisted slightly to the right.

Three angels hover near the top left corner of the inner 
framing lines.  Their gender is uncertain, although the outline of 
breasts on the left-most angel suggests a female.  The left-most and 
highest figure appears to be winged.  She faces forward and to the left, 
with her head bent back to turn her face upward.

Three winged angels hover near the top left corner of the 
inner framing lines.  Their gender is uncertain, but probably male.  The 
front-most angel holds a large, triangular harp and apparently plays it 
with his left hand.  His left arm is bent across his chest.  He is 
gowned and faces forward, with his head turned toward the right and 
slightly down.  His lower left leg and foot are extended slightly behind 
his right leg.  His bare feet are prominent.

The front-most angel in the group of three holds a large, 
triangular harp.

Three winged angels hover near the top left corner of the 
inner framing lines.  Their gender is uncertain, but probably male.  The 
middle angel is gowned and faces forward, with his head twisted to the 
left.  His left arm is at his side, with his left hand pointing downward 
with at least one extended finger.

Three winged angels hover near the top left corner of the 
inner framing lines.  Their gender is uncertain, but they are probably male.  The 
highest angel faces forward and to the right.  A line at his neck 
suggests that he is gowned, like his companions.

Grain stems, some with tassels, grow lower left in the 
side border.  Some arch over to the left.

Grain stems, some with tassels, grow lower right in the 
side border.  Some arch over to the right.

Two steps or a double plinth extend the entire length of 
the lower border design.  Two additional steps or plinths rise right and 
left toward the side borders, with grain stems above.  There may be an 
additional step lower right under the scroll.

An open book (showing a text) and a scroll fill the lower 
left border design.

An artist's palette rests in the center of the lower 
border design.

Four artist's brushes project from the finger hole in the 
palette at the center of the lower border design.  Above are two gravers 
(engraving tools).  The handle and shaft of one is pictured; we see only 
the handle of the other.

A scroll, the left end of which looks very leaf-like, 
rests in the lower right corner of the border design.

illusobjdesc.#text:
Seven winged angels, perhaps representing the seven days 
of creation in Genesis, hover in a semi-circle below the inscribed 
words.  Reading from top left to top right, we see an angel from behind, 
his hair long and his wings above his head with the tips touching; an 
angel with long hair, facing forward, holding a scroll and possibly a 
writing instrument of some sort; an angel with short curly hair hovering 
horizontally and facing forward, holding a scroll and quill; an angel 
with long hair, hovering horizontally, seen from behind but his face 
turned so that we see it in profile, possibly looking up; a long-haired 
angel facing forward with the top of a scroll just left of his right 
arm; a long-haired angel with wings raised, face seen in three-quarter 
view; and finally a long-haired angel facing forward, his wings raised 
with the tips touching.  We see only the heads and upper bodies of six 
of the angels; only the lowest angel's full body is pictured, legs 
extended to the right.  A horizontal line appears between the first and 
second lines of text; the decorative letter forms of several words 
suggest leaves or vines, particularly in the word "JOB."

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel 
top left is seen from behind.  His long hair falls over his back; his 
raised wings touch at their tips.

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel 
second from top left faces forward.  His hair is long; he holds a scroll 
and perhaps a writing instrument of some sort (as suggested by the very 
slight, elongated form just above his right hand adjacent to the left 
side of the scroll).  He may be writing (or have just left off writing, given 
the position of the instrument).

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel 
third from top left faces forward.  His hair is short and perhaps a bit 
curly.  He holds a scroll and a quill pen; he may be writing (or just 
left off writing, given the position of the quill).  Although most of 
his body is covered by his companion to the right, his body must be 
horizontal.

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the lowest winged 
angel is seen from behind, but with his face turned upward and to the 
right in profile.  His hair is long; his legs are together and extend 
horizontally to the right.

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel 
third from top right faces forward.  His hair is long; he holds a 
scroll, the curled end of which is visible just to the left of his right 
upper arm.  His wings, raised to the right, touch at their 
tips.

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel 
second from top right has long hair.  His wings extend upward to the 
right and may touch at their tips.  His body faces forward, but his head 
is turned partly to the left.

In the semi-circle of hovering angels, the winged angel 
top right faces forward.  His hair is long; the tips of his raised wings 
touch.

A cloud outline arches from the lower right and left sides 
of the second of two inner framing lines and curves below the imprint.  
Perhaps we are meant to imagine that the imprint is inscribed on the 
cloud.

note.#text: In a large arch across the top.

hi.#text: And there came a Messenger unto Job & said The Oxen were plowing & the Sabeans came down. & they have slain the Young Men with the Sword

note.#text: In an arch at the top.

hi.#text: Going to & fro in the Earth

l.#text: And I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
The fire of God is fallen from heaven & hath burned up the flocks & the
Young Men & consumed them. & only I am escaped alone to tell thee

note.#text: This line slants upwards slightly and curves, possibly in response to the design above it.

l.#text: London, Published as the Act directs March 8: 1825. by Will Blake N3 Fountain Court Strand.

illusobjdesc.#text:
A messenger runs, left to right, toward Job and his wife 
to tell them of the destruction of their family at Satan's hands.  He is 
gowned, from the waist down, and strides energetically toward the 
couple.  Job raises his hands as if in prayer; his wife lifts her hands, 
interdigitated, above her head.  A ram grazes far right, below the 
(stony?) seat or chair on which Job (and his wife?) sit.  A tree, 
perhaps an oak, rises along the right margin and extends its branches 
and leaves along the top margin of the design.  Two stone pillars form 
the background for Job and his wife; to the left are two grazing sheep 
and, in the background, a clump of trees.  The sky above and to the left 
is cloudy and stormy, an echo of the emotional condition.  Another 
messenger, perhaps nude but wearing a hat and holding a staff, strides 
energetically to the left in the middle background; another messenger 
runs on the hill in the distant background.  Trees and a Gothic 
building, perhaps a church, are pictured in the middle distance on the 
far left.  The foreground, raised into a mound, appears to be covered 
with grass and perhaps a few flowers below Job and his 
wife.

title: The Messengers Tell Job of His Misfortunes

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job's wife, gowned, sits next to her husband.  Her legs 
face to the left, but her upper body and head are twisted toward the 
viewer.  Her hair is long; she raises her slightly-bent arms vertically, 
with her palms together and her fingers interlinked, perhaps in prayer.  
Her face seems care-worn, perhaps with a mixture of grief and despair 
over the news of the her family's destruction.  Her breasts (as an emblem of 
her maternal role?) and bare left foot are prominent.

Job sits on the right.  He is gowned, with his hands 
together in prayer and his head back so that he looks up.  His long 
beard and hair cascade over his upper body.  His bare left foot is 
prominent.

A youthful and muscular male messenger runs in from the 
left side of the central design and toward Job and his wife.  He strides 
dramatically, legs spread; his right arm reaches back and points horizontally 
to the left, and his left arm is raised to the right at 135 degrees.  The fingers 
of both hands are slightly spread apart, and the palm of his left hand faces out.  His hair stands on end at the 
back of his head because of his onrushing speed.  His mouth is slightly 
open; he may be speaking as he approaches.  His facial features suggest 
a mixture of grief and fear.  His gown covers his body only from the 
waist to just above his knees, like a skirt, but with a belt or strap 
looped over his left shoulder.  His body faces forward, with his head 
turned almost completely to the right.  His bare feet are 
prominent.

A second male messenger strides energetically to the left 
in the middle distance, seen between the legs of the large messenger in 
the foreground.  He wears a hat and holds a staff, but there are no 
indications of clothing.  His body faces left, but his head is twisted 
to face the viewer, or even look back to the right.  Both arms are bent, 
his right in front of him to hold the staff, his left behind his 
back.

The tiny figure of a third male (?) messenger appears on 
the hill above the left arm of the second messenger.  He faces and 
strides energetically to the right, with at least one arm raised at 
about 135 degrees.

A Gothic (stone?) building, perhaps a church, appears 
lower left in the middle distance of the central design.  It has spires 
and arches, probably a door or two, and perhaps windows.

Two sheep graze in the middle distance, half their bodies 
covered by the stone pillar to the right.

Behind Job and his wife are two stone pillars.  The 
shading between the two hints at a third pillar or a 
wall.

Job sits on a (stone?) chair.  We do not see what his wife 
sits on; perhaps this is a bench-like seat that can accommodate 
two.

A ram, with a prominent and looping horn, grazes lower 
right.  We see only the front third of his body.

The foreground rises from lower left to right to form a 
slight mound on which the principal figures are disposed.

The foreground is grassy, with a few small plants and 
lily-like flowers below Job.

A large tree, perhaps an oak, grows up the right margin of 
the central design and spreads its large leaves just below the top 
margin.

A cluster of trees appears in the center of the central 
design, behind the grazing sheep and the left leg of the foreground 
messenger.

The short engraving strokes above and on each side of the 
Gothic building suggest trees rather than a background hill.  There may 
be a tree-trunk just to the left of the building.

An earthen bank descends just to the left of the 
messenger in the middle distance.  A small shadow extends from the 
messenger's left foot; there may also be a much larger shadow in the 
foreground associated with the large messenger.  Just above the bank, 
and below the Gothic building, may be a body of water, possibly a lake 
or river.

A hill or distant mountain (on which the tiny messenger 
runs) forms the horizon on the left side of the central 
design.

Dark clouds, suggesting a storm, fill the 
sky.

In the center of the top border, we see from behind a 
                     figure with bat-like wings—probably Satan.  He stands on a semi-circle 
(the rim of the earth?) and holds a sword in his left hand.  The point 
of the sword touches the semi-circle; Satan may be leaning on it, as one 
might use a walking-stick.  A shield appears just right of his right 
arm; it is unclear whether the shield is held in his right hand or 
buckled to his right arm.  His right foot is on tiptoe; he appears to be 
bald.  There is no evidence of clothing; he may be nude.

In the center of the top border, we see from behind a bat-
winged figure, very probably Satan, standing on a semi-circle.  This may 
be the rim of the earth.

Cloud outlines, bearing texts, fill the top border and 
descend half-way down the side borders.  Given the presence of flames 
below, it is possible that the outer-most cloud outlines are meant to be 
smoke.  The inner band of clouds surrounds Satan and the 
earth.

Beams of light radiate from the bat-winged figure of 
Satan.

A figure, probably female, lies on the top left corner of 
the inner framing lines.  It would appear that her body is twisted, with 
her lower body lying supine and her upper body lying prone.  Her legs 
may be crossed, one under the other; her head, long hair, and her 
left (?) arm dangle over the edge of the frame.  A few short lines 
suggest that she may be gowned.

A female figure lies supine on the top right corner of the 
inner framing lines.  Her head, long hair, and left arm dangle over the 
edge of the frame.  A few short lines suggest that she is 
gowned.

Flames undulate in the lower border.  Two tongues of fire 
reach upward on the left; one or two more arch around the lower right 
corner of the inner framing lines.  Perhaps we are to imagine that 
Blake's signature, lower right, is written on the flames.

A cloud outline appears above the flames in the lower 
margin.  A bolt of lightning shoots from it lower right.  Perhaps we are 
to imagine that the text immediately below the central design is written 
on the cloud.

A bolt of lightning shoots from a cloud just below the 
lower right corner of the inner framing lines.

The round object lower right may be ball lightning or 
perhaps a comet with spiky flames.

note.#text: In a large, flat curve across the top.

hi.#text: Did I not weep for him who was in trouble? Was not my Soul afflicted for the Poor

note.#text: In a tight curve.

hi.#text: Behold he is in thy hand: but save his Life

note.#text: Inscribed vertically in the right margin.

l.#text: Then went Satan forth from the presence of the Lord
And it grieved him at his heart
Who maketh his Angels Spirits & his Ministers a Flaming Fire
London, Published as the Act directs March 8: 1825. by Will Blake N3 Fountain Court Strand

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job and his wife sit side by side on a stone bench in the 
lower portion of the central design.  Her right hand is on her breast as 
she leans toward her husband.  Her left hand holds his right upper arm.  
Job holds a rectangular object, probably half a loaf of bread, in his 
right hand.  With his left hand he gives a similar half-loaf to an old 
man with a crutch and a dog on a leash.  Behind the recipient of Job's 
charity is a winged angel.  Another winged angel hovers on the left.  
The near foreground features grass and the leaves of small plants; in 
the middle distance on the left is a Druid trilithon; the horizon is 
defined by distant mountains with clouds above.  The upper portion of 
the central design portrays several dramatic figures, particularly 
Satan.  He is nude, with a slight suggestions of scales over his 
genitals, descending dramatically to the left.  He hold a vial in his 
right hand from which flames (?), perhaps indicative of pestilence, 
descend on Job.  Flames rise from this vessel and extend upward right 
and left, with clouds on their outer margins.  On the left are six 
hovering figures, probably angels although without wings.  Their six 
symmetrical companions on the right are similarly arranged in the 
ascending flames.  In the center of this oval composition, God sits on a 
stone throne, raised on a plinth.  He leans to the left and holds a book 
in his right hand, a scroll in his left.  A large and radiant halo 
surrounds his head and upper body.

title: Satan Going Forth from the Presence of the Lord and Job's Charity

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job sits at the center of the lower portion of the central 
design.  He is gowned, but his bare right foot extends beyond the hem of 
his garment.  His left leg may be crossed behind his right at the 
ankles.  He is bearded and his hair is long.  His right arm is bent, and his right hand, resting in 
his lap, holds half a loaf of bread; his left arm is extended 
horizontally and he holds in his hand another half-loaf.  He gives this 
bread to an old man on crutches.

Job holds two half-loaves of bread; one rests in his lap, 
held by his right hand, the other is held in his left 
hand.

Job's wife sits beside him.  She is gowned and has long 
hair.  Her bare left foot is visible beneath the hem of her garment.  
She leans toward her husband, with her left hand, fingers spread, 
holding his upper left arm.  Her right arm is bent, with her right hand 
resting on her breast.

A gowned and winged angel hovers near the lower left 
margin.  His hands are together in prayer as he faces forward and to the 
right.  His head and long hair are surrounded by a halo.

A gowned and winged angel hovers near the lower right 
margin.  His hands are together in prayer, fingers slightly spread 
apart, as he faces forward and to the left.  His hair is long; his head 
may be surrounded by a halo (like his companion on the left), but this 
may only be the upper arch of his right wing.

An old man leaning on a crutch stands facing to the left 
with his eyes cast down or closed.  He may be blind.  His left leg is bent behind his 
right.  His hair, beard, and gown are long; his bare left foot is 
prominent.  He apparently holds the dog's leash with his unpictured 
right hand; his left arm is bent at the elbow and extended to receive an 
object (probably a small loaf of bread) from Job.  The fingers of his 
left hand are spread slightly apart.  He may be a beggar.

A small dog, head down and perhaps sniffing the ground, 
appears just to the right of Job.  A thin leash extends from the dog's 
collar toward the old man on the right.

Job and his wife sit on a bench or seat of some sort, 
probably made of stone.

A few plants (with spiky leaves) and grass are pictured 
just above the lower margin of the central design.  There may be more 
vegetation in the middle distance, including trees or bushes on the 
right behind the old man with a crutch.

Hills and mountains dominate the landscape background 
behind Job and his wife.

A stone trilithon appears in the middle distance just to 
the left of Job's wife.

The hatching lines in the sky above Job and his wife hint 
at clouds that grow darker left and right.

God sits, enthroned, in the top center of the design.  He 
is old and bearded, has long hair, and wears a gown.  His bare feet are 
both prominent, particularly the right foot.  He reaches down to 
hold a book (right hand) and a scroll (left hand).  The fingers of his 
right hand are spread slightly apart.  His left leg is slightly bent at 
the knee but extends downward; his right leg is bent sharply at the knee 
and drawn up toward his torso.  He faces forward but leans to the left.  
A halo-like burst of radiance with beams of light forms a backdrop for 
his head and upper body and extends toward the circle of angels on both 
sides.
God holds a book in his right hand.
God holds a scroll in his left hand.

God sits, enthroned, on a chair or seat of some sort.  Its 
rounded arms can be seen left and right of his forearms.

God's throne and both his feet rest on a three-step plinth, 
probably made of stone.

Satan, a youthful and nude male, hovers (or flies rapidly) 
beneath God.  His short curly hair rises in two arcs above his forehead 
in a manner that suggests horns.  There are slight suggestions of 
scales, or at least oddly roughened skin, on his lower abdomen and over 
his genitals.  The position of his limbs suggests dramatic movement, 
perhaps descending or curving from right to left.  He faces forward, 
with his head twisted upward toward God.  His mouth is slightly open, as 
though speaking.  His left leg is extended up and to the right; his 
right leg is bent sharply at the knee and drawn up toward his upper 
right thigh.  His left arm, bent slightly at the elbow, is extended over 
his head and to the left (but raised vertically relative to his body); 
his right arm is extended downward but at an angle of 135 degrees 
relative to his torso.  The palm of his left hand faces down.  The 
fingers of his left hand are spread slightly apart.  He holds a vial in 
his right hand from which descends either a liquid or fire.  Both feet 
are prominent.

Satan holds a vial in his right hand.  A liquid, or 
perhaps fire, descends from it toward Job.  This may represent the 
diseases that will plague Job.

Satan is surrounded by flames that my be issuing from 
behind the vial in his right hand.  Other flames back the angels 
surrounding God, right and left.  Behind the flame are bands of clouds 
or possibly smoke.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the left of God.  We 
see only the heads of the two uppermost figures.  The one on the left 
has long hair, the one on the right short (?) and curly 
hair.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the left of God.  We 
see only the head, and perhaps a bit of the right shoulder and back, of 
the third angel from the top, just left of the angel with a raised right 
hand.  He has long hair and faces right.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the left of God.  We 
see only the head, upper body, and raised right hand (palm out) of the 
fourth angel from the top, just right of the angel facing right.  He has 
long hair and faces forward.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the left of God.  The 
second angel from the bottom of the group wears a gown and is twisted to 
face left, forward, right, and down.  Both arms are bent at the elbow 
with hands raised.  The right hand faces palm out, the right palm up 
with fingers slightly spread.  The figure's hair is long; the bare left 
foot is prominent.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the left of God.  We 
see the lowest figure in the group from behind, but his body is twisted 
to the right and his face looks to the right.  He is gowned, but with a 
prominent bare left foot.  His hair is long and his arms are bent 
forward, with the palms of both hands facing out with fingers 
spread.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the right of God.  We 
see only the heads of the two top figures.  They face forward and to the 
left; both have long hair.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the right of God.  We 
see only the head and upper body of the figure third from the top.  He 
is gowned and has long hair.  His left arm may be bent upward across, 
and partly wrapped around, his chest.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the right of God.  We 
see only the head, upper body, and right arm of the figure fourth from 
the top (just slightly below and to the left of the third figure from 
the top).  He is gowned and has long hair; he faces forward with his 
head turned a little downward.  His right arm is bent upward across, and 
partly wrapped around, his chest.  The fingers of his right hand are 
spread apart.

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the right of God.  We 
see the second figure from the bottom from behind, but his head is 
twisted down and to the left so that we see his face in left profile.  
He is gowned and has long hair.  His legs and the lower reaches of his 
gown seem to merge with the surrounding flames.  His hands, with fingers 
spread, are raised with palms out (relative to his body).

Six figures, probably male angels, hover to the right of God.  We 
see the lowest figure from behind, but his head is twisted to the left 
so that we see his face in left profile.  He is gowned and has long 
hair.  His bare right foot is prominent.  His arms are bent sharply 
upward at the elbows; his hands, with fingers spread, are raised with 
palms out (relative to his body).

Flames would appear to issue from the bottom center of the 
border design and ascend in both side borders.  Tongues of flames extend 
toward each other in the top border.  The forms intertwined with the 
thorny vines in each side border may also be flames—or very flame-like 
vines.

A thorny vine twists up the left border.  It is 
intertwined with a flame (or a very flame-like vine) to form a Tree of 
Jesse motif.

A thorny vine twists up the right border.  It is 
intertwined with a flame (or a very flame-like vine) to form a Tree of 
Jesse motif.

Two scaly snakes dominate the lower border design.  Their 
tails are intertwined with the thorny vines in the left and right 
margins.  In the lower center of the design is the head of only one snake, 
facing left.  The creature's one visible eye seems to look 
upward.

A winged angel, probably male, decorates the top left 
corner of the inner frame.  He is gowned and has flame-like hair; his 
large wing extends horizontally along the top edge of the frame.  His 
right arm is bent sharply upward at the elbow and his head rests on his 
upraised right hand. His left arm may be drawn back, although we see 
only his left shoulder and a bit of the upper arm.  The figure suggests 
melancholy touched by surprise or fear.

A winged angel, probably male, decorates the top right 
corner of the inner frame.  He is probably gowned (or holds a cloak 
before him) and has flame-like hair; his large wing extends horizontally 
along the top edge of the frame.  His left arm is bent sharply upward at 
the elbow and his head rests on his upraised left hand. His right arm 
may be under his gown or cloak and drawn up toward his neck to hold the 
garment.  The figure suggests melancholy touched by surprise or 
fear.

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job, in his misery, lies upon a bed of straw, his head 
bent back, arms stiffened at his side, his palms raised with fingers 
spread.  The rough texture of his flesh suggests the sore boils that 
afflict him.  He rests is feet against his wife, kneeling and hunched 
over at his feet, her head down and in her hands in grief and despair.  
She is gowned; Job's loins are covered with a rough (burlap?) cloth.  A 
triumphant Satan stands above Job, his feet resting on Job's right thigh 
and abdomen.  Satan is nude, but we can clearly see scales on his hips, 
upper legs, and over his genital area.  His arms are raised 
horizontally; four arrows descend from just behind his right hand.  He 
holds a vial in his left hand from which spills either a liquid or 
flames.  A (mock?) halo surrounds his head.  The background is dominated 
by billowing clouds (of smoke?) and a sun that is rising or (more 
probably) setting over the ocean on the far left.  Ruined walls or 
buildings, a broken cromlech or portal, and broken columns appear in the 
folds of the hills in the middle distance and background.  A mountain 
rises in the horizon, its peak obscured by Satan's body.  A few spiky 
plants or grass appear in the near foreground, just above the lower 
margin of the central design.

Job lies supine on a bed of straw.  His body seems rigid, 
with his head bent back in an expression of extreme pain.  His hair and 
beard are long; the rough texture of his flesh suggests the sore boils 
that plague him.  His arms are at his side, with palms raised and 
fingers spread.  He is nude except for a rough (burlap?) cloth that 
covers his loins.  His prominent bare feet rest on the legs of his 
kneeling wife.
Job lies on a bed or mound of straw.

Job's wife kneels at her husband's feet, which touch her 
thighs.  She is gowned; her hair his long.  She is bent over in a 
contracted posture, with her head down and her face covered by her 
upraised hands.  We see her bare right foot.  Her posture suggests 
despair.

A muscular Satan triumphs over Job, his feet resting on 
Job's right thigh and abdomen.  He faces forward, looking down toward 
Job, with legs spread apart and arms raised horizontally.  His mouth is 
open, with the suggestion of a sardonic smile; his hair is short and 
curly.  His head and neck are twisted downward and to the right; his 
torso leans to the right.  He is nude, but scales are clearly pictured 
on his thighs, hips, and genital area.  Four arrows descend from behind 
his raised right hand, palm out.  He holds a vial in his left hand, from 
which descends a liquid or flames.  A (mock?) halo surrounds his 
head.

Four arrows descend from (or from behind) Satan's raised 
right hand.  They may emblemize the diseases that plague 
Job.

Satan holds in his left hand a vial from which descends a 
liquid or flames.  These may emblemize the diseases that plague 
Job.

Grass or spiky plants appear in the lower margin of the 
central design.  The mottled texture of the hills in the middle distance 
also suggest vegetation of some sort.

Low hills dominate the middle distance.  A mountain rises 
on the horizon, its peak obscured by Satan's body.

A sun rises (or more probably sets) above the ocean.  
Beams of light and radiance fill the sky.

Billowing clouds (of smoke?) fill the sky on both sides of 
Satan.

A ruined wall, perhaps of a building, appears behind Job's 
head.  Just to the left, and further in the distance, is another 
structure, probably also a ruin.  Both are probably made of 
stone.

A ruined structure, possibly a (stone?) portal with post 
and lintel or a trilithon, appears in the middle distance just left of 
Satan's lower right leg.  Just above, and further in the distance, are 
three structures, perhaps ruined walls or pillars.  All are probably 
stone.

Two steps or plinths adorn the lower left corner of the 
lower border design.

The two pieces of a broken shepherd's crook appear in the 
lower left corner of the lower border design.

A grasshopper stands, facing right, in the lower border 
design.

A broken pot or pitcher is pictured in the center of the 
lower border design.

Spiky vegetation, perhaps grass, two very spiky (holly or 
thistle?) leaves, a large (oak or ivy?) leaf, and three thistle flowers 
adorn the right half of the lower border design.

The head of a frog (or lizard?) emerges from the 
vegetation in the lower border design.  The webbed left foot of the 
creature suggests a frog rather than a lizard.

Part of a pot is pictured in the lower border design, just 
to the right of the head of the lizard or frog.

A spider dangles at the end of a filament of web 
                     descending down the left margin.  The spider has its head down—the 
opposite of its companion in the right margin.  Since the filament 
extends from back of the spider's abdomen, where the spinneret is 
located, it may be spinning the web.

A spider dangles at the end of a filament of web 
                     descending down the right margin.  The spider has its head up—the 
opposite of its companion in the right margin.  The spider may be 
climbing up the filament it has just spun.

A bat-winged angel or devil adorns the top left corner of 
the inner framing lines.  The figure is probably male and either gowned 
or nude.  His left arm is extended horizontally along the top framing 
line; his lowered right hand holds the end of a filament of a spider's 
web.  His hair is short and may be curly.  See also the companion figure 
at the top right corner of the inner framing lines.

A bat-winged angel or devil adorns the top right corner of 
the inner framing lines.  The figure is probably male and either gowned 
or nude.  His right arm is extended horizontally along the top framing 
line; his lowered left hand holds the end of a filament of a spider's 
web.  His hair is short.  See also the companion figure at the top left 
corner of the inner framing lines.

A bat-winged angel or devil sits or reclines, facing 
forward and to the right, on a cloud outline.  He or she (note the 
slight suggestion of female breasts) has the right arm extended back for 
support; the left arm is raised vertically.  The legs are crossed below 
the knee.

A bat-winged angel or devil soars rightward (and slightly 
down) through the sky.  The figure's gender is uncertain.  It's legs are 
spread slightly apart and its left arm is extended horizontally to the 
right (but vertically in relation to the body).

Several cloud outlines, bearing texts, are pictured in the 
top marginal design.

they lifted up their voice & wept. & they rent every Man his

Ye have heard of the Patience of Joband have seen the end of the Lord.

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job sits on the right in his misery, nude except for a 
rough (burlap?) cloth over his lap.  He appears to be resting 
uncomfortably on a bed of straw piled into a mound (or covering a mound 
of earth).  The rough texture of his flesh suggests the sore boils that afflict him.  His expression suggests despair and pain. His head is 
twisted to the right, eyes looking upward (for solace?), and mouth 
slightly parted.  His arms are bent at his side, with the fingers of his 
left hand spread slightly apart.  His wife stands behind him, her arms 
sharply bent upward and her palms out (fingers spread) in an expression 
of despair and grief.  Her head is twisted to the left and her mouth 
slightly parted.  Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands 
raised, on the left.  Eliphaz the Temanite is the figure leading the 
group; his identity is made clear in object 11 (plate numbered 9).  If 
the friends enter in the same order as they are introduced in Job 2:11, 
then the next figure to the left is Bildad the Shuhite and farthest to 
the left is Zophar the Naamathite.  Various ruined walls, buildings, and 
perhaps one trilithon adorn the hills in the middle distance.  Other 
walls or pillars anchor the far right margin.  The near foreground 
contains some grass and, lower right, some thorny vines.  The mottled 
texture of the hills in the middle distance suggests more vegetation.  A 
burst of light (from a setting sun?) radiates above the distant 
mountains.

Job sits on the right in his misery, nude except for a 
rough (burlap?) cloth over his lap.  He leans back against his wife.  He 
appears to be resting uncomfortably on a bed of straw on top of a mound 
(of earth?).  The rough texture of his flesh suggests the sore boils 
that afflict him.  His expression suggests despair and pain. His body 
faces left and forward, but his head is twisted to the right, eyes 
looking upward (for solace?), and mouth slightly parted.  He may be 
speaking or crying out in pain.  His arms are bent at his side, with the 
fingers of his left hand spread slightly apart.  His right hand rests on 
a mound of straw or earth.  His hair and beard are long; his bare feet 
are prominent.

Job lies on a bed of straw, apparently piled into a mound 
or spread over a mound of earth.  There is another mound under his right 
hand; a third mound (covered with vegetation?) rises above the straw 
left of Job's right hand.

Job's wife stands or kneels behind him, her arms bent sharply upward 
at the elbows, palms out (and slightly up) and fingers spread. Her expression is that of grief and despair.  She is gowned, has long hair, and 
faces forward, with her head twisted to the left and down.  She looks 
down upon Job.  Her mouth is slightly open; she may be speaking or 
crying out in lamentation.

Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands 
raised, on the left.  Eliphaz the Temanite is the figure leading the 
group; his identity is made clear in object 11 (plate numbered 9).  His 
hair is fairly long, but not as long as his flowing beard.  He is gowned 
and faces right; both of his bare feet and the agitated hem of his garment are 
prominent.  The fingers of both raised hands (palms up or out) are 
spread apart.  His mouth is open, as though speaking.  His visage 
suggests grief and surprise.

Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands 
raised, on the left.  If the friends enter in the same order as they are 
introduced in Job 2:11, then the middle figure is Bildad the Shuhite.  
His hair and beard are curly.  He is gowned and faces right; his bare 
right foot is pictured.  The fingers of both raised hands (palms up or 
out) are spread apart.  His head is bent back so that his head faces up; 
his mouth is open, as though speaking or possibly 
praying.

Job's three friends enter in a rush, arms and hands 
raised, on the left.  If the friends enter in the same order as they are 
introduced in Job 2:11, then the last figure on the left is Zophar the 
Naamathite.  We see only his arms, head, and upper body.  His hair would 
appear to be long; only a bit of his beard on his right cheek is 
pictured.  He is gowned and faces right.  The fingers of both raised 
hands (palms up) are spread apart.  His head is bent back so that his 
head faces up.

Walls and/or pillars, perhaps of a (ruined?) building, 
rise along the right margin of the central design.  There are also two 
steps, lower right.  All these structures would appear to be made of 
stone.

A low (stone?) wall forms the backdrop for Job's right 
lower arm and hand.

Several ruined structures rise among the hills in the 
middle distance of the central design.  These include walls (of 
buildings?), broken pillars, and a trilithon.  All are probably made of 
stone.

Some grass, a few spiky plants, and some thorny branches 
(lower right, with a few leaves) adorn the foreground just above the 
lower margin of the central design.  The reticulated surface of a large 
bush or hedge, or a mound cover with indeterminate vegetation, appears 
between the low wall (left of Job's left hand) and the left knee of the 
right-most friend on the left.

The middle distance is dominated by low hills, with larger 
mountains on the horizon.  Above these are spiky beams of light and a 
                     burst of radiance, probably from a rising—or more probably setting—sun.

The lower border design is a landscape with low hills and 
a clump of trees on the left.

The lower border design is a landscape with low hills and 
a clump of trees on the left.

A shepherd with long hair, possibly female, stands and 
leans against a tree in the lower left corner of the border design.  One 
leg is extended backward, as though for support.  Her arms are crossed 
at the wrists; she holds a shepherd's crook in her left hand.  She is 
gowned and faces to the right, but with her head turned toward us and 
bent down.  Her eyes may be closed—or at least turned 
downward.

A dog sits in the lower right corner of the border design.  
His head is twisted up to look at the shepherd.

An aged shepherd, with long hair and beard, stands (facing 
left) and leans against a leafless tree in the lower right corner of the 
border design.  He is apparently holding the shepherd's crook that 
extends above his head; his left arm may be bent at the elbow.  His head 
is bent down; his eyes may be closed—or at least turned 
down.

A sheep and a ram, the latter with a looped horn, lie 
prone just to the left of the shepherd in the lower 
right corner of the border design.  They may be sleeping with eyes 
                     closed and are facing left.

A leafless tree rises from the lower left corner of the 
border design.  Its branches extend half-way up the left 
border.

A leafless tree rises from the lower right corner of the 
border design.  Its branches extend half-way up the right 
border.

Cloud outlines extend through the upper border design and 
extend down both side borders.  The central cloud bears a 
text.

A gowned figure, probably female, sits on the top left 
corner of the inner framing lines.  Her bent and crossed legs dangle 
into the left side border.  She faces to the left and is bent over, with 
her head down and resting in her raised left hand.  Her hair is long and 
her eyes may be closed (or at least turned down).  Her posture suggests 
despair, melancholy, or grief.

A gowned figure, probably female, sits on the top right 
corner of the inner framing lines.  Her bent legs dangle into the right 
side border.  She faces to the right and is bent over, with her head 
down and resting in her raised left hand.  Her right arm, bent at the 
elbow, rests in her lap.  Her hair is long and her eyes may be closed 
(or at least turned down).  Her posture suggests despair, melancholy, or 
grief.

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job, in his agony and despair, sits on a bed of straw in 
the middle of the central design.  He is nude except for a rough 
(burlap?) cloth over his lap.  He faces forward, with knees drawn up and 
both feet prominent.  His arms are raised vertically, with the palms of 
his raised hands up and out.  His hair is probably long; tears cascade 
down his cheeks and long beard.  His mouth is open; he may be speaking 
or crying out in pain.  The rough texture of his flesh suggests the 
boils that afflict him.  To the left is Job's wife, kneeling and hunched 
over in grief and despair.  Her contracted body, facing right, is 
gowned; her long hair cascades over her face.  On the right, also 
kneeling and hunched over with faces obscured, are Job's three friends.  
If our identifications in object 9 (the plate numbered 7) are correct, then 
these are (from left to right) Eliphaz (or possibly Zophar), Bildad, and 
Zophar (or possibly Eliphaz).  All are gowned.  A few spikes of grass, a 
thorny branch, and perhaps some stones (lower right) adorn the 
foreground.  An archway, with heavy post and lintel, stands in the 
middle distance on the right.  A low hill, possibly covered with 
vegetation, extends through the entire middle distance.  Behind this whole scene are a 
range of mountains and a stormy sky filled with dark clouds and possibly 
smoke.

Job, in his agony and despair, sits on a bed of straw in 
the middle of the central design.  He is nude except for a rough 
(burlap?) cloth over his lap.  He faces forward, with knees drawn up and 
both feet prominent.  His arms are raised vertically, with the palms of 
his raised hands up and out.  His hair is probably long; tears cascade 
down his cheeks and long beard.  His mouth is open; he may be speaking 
or crying out in pain.  The rough texture of his flesh suggests the 
boils that afflict him.

Job sits on a bed of straw piled into a 
mound.

Job's wife kneels to the left of her husband.  She is 
hunched over in a posture expressive of grief and despair.  Her 
contracted body, facing right, is gowned; her long hair cascades over 
her face.

Job's three friends kneel, facing left, in severely 
contracted postures expressive of grief or despair.  Their faces are 
hidden, and all three figures wear gowns.  Given their 
identifications we have proposed in object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the 
front-most figure is either Eliphaz (although his hair is much longer 
here than in object 9) or Zophar.  His left arm is bent sharply at the 
elbow as he reaches forward with his left hand (fingers spread) over his 
cascading hair.

Job's three friends kneel, facing left, in severely 
contracted postures expressive of grief or despair.  Their faces are 
hidden, and all three figures wear gowns.  Given their 
identifications we have proposed in object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the 
middle figure is probably Bildad (note the curly hair).

Job's three friends kneel, facing left, in severely 
contracted postures expressive of grief or despair.  Their faces are 
hidden, and all three figures wear gowns.  Given their 
identifications we have proposed in object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the 
last figure in the group, closest to Job, is probably Zophar, although 
he might be Eliphaz.  We see only the top of his head, covered with 
(long?) hair. A pair of clasped hands probably belongs to this last figure in the group.

A bit of spiky vegetation, probably grass and a short 
thorny vine or branch, appears below Job's wife and just above the lower 
left margin of the central design.

A few plants and a bit of grass appear below Job's friends 
and just above the lower right margin of the central design.  The 
rounded forms might be either lobed leaves or stones.

A low hill fills the middle distance behind the 
figures.

The reticulated surface of the low hill in the middle 
distance suggests vegetation of some sort.

Dark mountains define the horizon in the central design.  
The mountain peak on the left seems oddly tilted to the 
left.

Dark clouds fill the sky in the central design.  The most 
prominent billows upward, and thus these may be clouds of smoke from the 
continued destruction of Job's world.

An archway, with heavy stone post and lintel, dominates 
the middle distance behind Job's friends.

Cloud outlines adorn the upper border design.  The text 
appears to float on the cloud.

A cloud outline, with drops of rain descending from it, 
appears in the lower left margin.

A cloud outline, with drops of rain descending from it, 
appears in the lower right margin.

A thorny, snake-like vine extends along the lower border 
of the lower marginal design.

Several plants appear in the lower left margin.  These 
are, from left to right, a plant or small tree with branches bearing 
flowers and fruit, spiky grass, a large mushroom, and either a cluster 
of small mushrooms or a plant with leaves at the end of short 
stems.

Several plants appear in the lower right margin.  These 
are, from right to left, a plant with spiky leaves and branches bearing 
flowers and fruit, a thistle, spiky grass, either a cluster of small 
mushrooms or a plant with leaves at the end of short stems, and a large 
mushroom.

note.#text: In a very long curve over the top half of the plate. Above the printed word "God" in this line, there appears another, very faint rendering of the word "God". This displaced rendering of "God" is probably a remnant of Blake's preliminary execution of his letters in drypoint.

hi.#text:
Shall mortal Man be more 
Just than God?  Shall a Man be more Pure than
his Maker? Behold he putteth no trust

in his Saints 
& his Angels he chargeth with folly

l.#text:
Then a Spirit passed before my 
Face

the hair of my flesh stood 
up

illusobjdesc.#text:
Eliphaz kneels, lower right, with left arm raised as he 
tells his vision of God to Job and his wife.  Job's two other friends, 
Bildad and Zophar, kneel near the right margin.  Job, again on his bed of 
straw, looks upward to the vision of God, standing, with a halo and 
beams of light around him.  Eliphaz, in his vision above, is in bed, his 
hand gesture and hair standing on end indicating his fear of God.  The 
vision in the sky is surrounded by dark cloud bands.  Below, in a 
landscape defined by a dark sky and mountains on the horizon, we also 
find Job's wife, seated on the far left and with her face turned upward.  
A few blades of grass and perhaps small plants adorn the foreground just 
above the lower border of the central design.

Job sits or reclines on his bed of straw.  His knees, 
drawn up, are covered by a rough (burlap?) cloth; his left foot pokes 
out from below this garment.  His upper body is unclothed.  He props up 
his body with his left arm, bent at the elbow; his right arm is bent 
across his chest, with the fingers of his right hand spread apart.  His 
body faces forward, but his head is twisted up to look at the vision of 
God in the sky.  His hair and beard are long.

Job reclines on a bed or low mound of 
straw.

Job's wife sits or kneels in the lower left corner of the 
central design.  She faces forward, but she twists her head upward to 
look at the vision of God above.  She is gowned, with her right arm by 
her side and her right hand on the ground.  Her left arm is bent at the 
elbow, with her right hand across her breast.  Her mouth is slightly 
open; she may be speaking.

Eliphaz kneels lower right, his left arm and hand (palm 
up) raised toward his vision of God he is describing to Job.  He is 
gowned and faces left; his beard and hair are long.  His right arm 
extends toward his knees, upon which his right hand 
rests.

Two of Job's friends kneel or sit near the lower right 
margin of the central design.  Given our identifications of the friends 
in object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the friend farthest to the left is Bildad (note 
the curly hair and beard).  He is gowned and faces left, with his head 
twisted up and to the right.  His hands are clasped together under his 
chin in an attitude of prayer.  His mouth may be slightly 
open.

Two of Job's friends kneel or sit near the lower right 
margin of the central design.  Given our identifications of the friends 
in object 9 (the plate numbered 7), the third figure from the front is 
probably Zophar.  He is probably kneeling, like his companion, but we 
can see only his upturned face.  His mouth may be slightly open (in 
prayer?).

In Eliphaz's vision, pictured in the sky, God stands as an 
ancient patriarch with long hair and beard.  He is gowned and faces 
right, his right arm apparently bent at the elbow and extended over his 
chest beneath his garment.  He appears to be looking directly at Eliphaz 
to the right.  His head is surrounded by a halo.

In Eliphaz's vision, pictured in the sky, his visionary 
self appears.  He reclines in a bed, his body propped up against a 
pillow.  He faces left and has a long beard.  His hair stands on end, 
indicating fright at the vision of God before him.  His left arm is bent 
at the elbow, with the palm of his left hand (fingers slightly spread) 
facing toward God.  Eliphaz wears a gown (nightgown?), or at least a 
shirt.  His mouth may be open slightly and his eyes are wide open as he 
beholds his vision of God.

In his vision, Eliphaz lies in bed, a sheet covering his 
body up to the chest.  There would appear to be a pillow behind his 
head.

Beams of light and radiance extend outward from God, and 
from his halo, in the vision in the sky.  Some shafts extend downward 
from below God and across the dark cloud separating the vision in the 
sky from the figures on the earth below.

Eliphaz's vision in the sky is framed by dark cloud 
bands.

The foreground just above the lower margin of the central 
design is adorned with some grass and perhaps (below Eliphaz) a small 
plant.

The horizon, in the lower portion of the central design, 
is defined by distant mountains.

The sky, between the mountains of the lower portion of the 
central design and the cloud-framed vision above, is defined by hatching 
lines that hint at dark clouds.  This may be a night (or twilight) 
scene.

Cloud outlines extend through the upper border design and 
extend half-way down both margins.  A text appears to be written on this 
cloud.

The line surrounding the inscription in the lower border 
design may be a cloud outline bearing a text.

The trunks and branches of leafless (and dead?) trees 
extend up the left margin.

The trunks and branches of leafless (and dead?) trees 
extend up the right margin.

A few hatching lines, lower right in the border design, 
hint at blades of grass.

l.#text: But he knoweth the way that I take
when he hath tried me I shall come forth like gold
Have pity upon me! Have pity upon me! O ye my friends
for the hand of God hath touched me
Though he slay me yet will I trust in him
The Just Upright Man is laughed to scorn
Man that is born of a Woman is of few days & full of trouble
he cometh up like a flower & is cut down. he fleeth also as a shadow
& continueth not, And dost thou open thine eyes upon such a one
& bringest me into judgment with thee

note.#text: Inscribed vertically in the lower right margin.

illusobjdesc.#text:
Job kneels on his bed of straw, center left, his mouth 
slightly open and tears running down his cheeks and long beard.  He is 
nude above the waist; a piece of rough (burlap?) cloth covers his loins 
and legs.  His hands are down by his thighs, palms out.  The rough 
texture of his flesh, particularly visible on his lower arms, suggests 
the boils that plague him.  His eyes appear to be turned slightly 
upward, as though he is beseeching his God.  His posture, visage, and 
gestures suggest pain and despair.  Job's wife sits far left, her head 
twisted toward her husband.  Her hair is long; her face now looks a good 
deal older than in earlier scenes.  Two tears drop from her right eye.  
Both feet extend from under the hem of her gown.  Her knees are drawn up 
sharply toward her chest, with both arms wrapped around them.  Her hands 
are open, fingers spread, in a gesture that suggests she is questioning 
Job and his fate.  Job's three friends (probably Eliphaz, Bildad, and 
Zophar, front to back) sit, squat, or stand on the right.  They are 
gowned and point accusatory arms, hands, and fingers at Job.  The middle 
distance is filled with a low hill, perhaps covered with vegetation.  A 
small, flowering (?) plant grows on the hill just below the outstretched 
left hand of the front-most friend/accuser.  A bit of vegetation, 
probably grass, adorns the foreground just above the lower margin of the 
central design.  A large pillar, or section of a wall, anchors the left 
margin; much smaller structures, perhaps broken columns and ruined 
walls, appear near the right margin in the middle distance.  The horizon 
is defined by dark mountains; above, the sky is stormy, with dark 
clouds.  The unengraved area in the sky, upper left just above the 
mountains, suggests a feeble light, perhaps from a rising (but more 
probably setting) sun.

Job kneels, facing forward, on his bed of straw, center 
left, his mouth slightly open and tears running down his cheeks and long 
beard.  He is nude above the waist; a piece of rough (burlap?) cloth 
covers his loins and legs.  His hair is long and his hands are down by 
his thighs, palms out.  The rough texture of his flesh, particularly 
visible on his lower arms, suggests the boils that plague him.  His eyes 
appear to be turned slightly upward, as though he is beseeching his God.  
His posture, visage, and gestures suggest pain and 
despair.

Job's wife sits far left, her head twisted toward her 
husband.  Her hair is long; her face now looks a good deal older than in 
earlier scenes.  Two tears drop from her right eye.  Both feet extend 
from under the hem of her gown.  Her knees are drawn up sharply toward 
her chest, with both arms wrapped around them.  Her hands are open, 
fingers spread, in a gesture that suggests she, in her despair, is 
pointing toward and questioning Job and their shared 
fate.

Job's three friends appear on the right in the central 
design.  Given our identifications of the friends in object 9 (the plate 
numbered 7), the front-most figure is probably Eliphaz.  He sits with 
his right knee on the ground and his left knee drawn up toward his 
torso.  He is old, bearded, and gowned, with long hair.  His left foot 
extends from under the hem of his garment.  His body faces forward, 
turned somewhat to the left, as looks toward Job and raises both arms 
horizontally and points, with an accusatory gesture, toward Job.  His 
extended fingers are spread apart, particularly on his left 
hand.

Job's three friends appear on the right in the central 
design.  Given our identifications of the friends in object 9 (the plate 
numbered 7), the second figure from the front is very probably Bildad.  
He is gowned, with curly hair and beard.  He would appear to be sitting 
or squatting on the ground; we can see his right knee and right foot.  His 
body probably faces to the left, with his head turned toward us, but he 
would appear to be looking at Job.  He raises both arms horizontally and 
points, with an accusatory gesture, toward Job.  His extended fingers 
are spread apart, particularly on his left hand.

Job's three friends appear on the right of the central 
design.  Given our identifications of the friends in object 9 (the plate 
numbered 7), the third and last figure from the front is probably 
Zophar.  He is gowned, with long hair and beard, and his right foot extends from the hem of his gown.  He is probably 
standing, given his height relative to his companions.  His body 
probably faces to the left, with his head turned toward us, but he would 
appear to be looking at Job.  He raises both arms horizontally and 
points, with an accusatory gesture, toward Job.  His extended fingers 
are spread apart.

Job's bed or mound of straw appears just to the right of 
his left arm, beneath his knees and his wife's feet, and apparently 
extends behind both figures.

Some vegetation, perhaps grass with small plants and 
vines, appears below the feet of the front-most of Job's  accusatory 
friends.

The reticulated surfaces of the hills in the middle 
distance suggest vegetation of some sort.

A small plant, with leaves and perhaps buds or flowers, 
appears just below the extended left hand of the front-most of Job's 
accusatory friends.

A wall or pillar of stone rises upper left in the central 
design.

Ruined pillars, with perhaps fragments of broken (stone?) 
walls, appear in the middle distance just to the right of the upper back 
of the middle figure in the group of Job's three accusatory 
friends.

The landscape background for the figures is composed of 
hills in the middle distance and a range of mountains on the 
horizon.

Crepuscular radiance, perhaps caused by a sunrise or (more 
probably) a sunset, glows just above the distant mountain range, 
particularly on the left.

A dark (storm?) cloud hovers in the sky, upper left in the 
central design.  Horizontal lines of hatching elsewhere in the sky 
suggest more clouds, or at least darkness.

Arching lines in the upper border design suggest the sides 
of an arch or dome.

A figure, probably a gowned and youthful male with long 
hair, clings to (or climbs up?) the top left corner of the inner framing 
lines.  Although they are not individually pictured, his legs apparently 
dangle into the left border.  He faces right, with at least his left arm 
extended horizontally to the right.  A large chain extends from him down 
the left border.

A figure, probably a gowned (?) male with a beard, clings 
to (or climbs up?) the top right corner of the inner framing lines.  His 
legs dangle into the right border.  He faces left, with at least his 
right arm extended horizontally to the left.  A large chain extends from 
him down the right border.

A large chain descends from the figure clinging to the top 
left corner of the inner framing lines.

A large chain descends from the figure clinging to the top 
right corner of the inner framing lines.

A bat-like wing decorates the lower left corner of the 
inner framing lines.  Perhaps we are to imagine that a very large (and 
Satanic?) bat is hidden behind the central design, his wings projecting 
on either side of it.

A bat-like wing decorates the lower right corner of the 
inner framing lines.  Perhaps we are to imagine that a very large (and 
Satanic?) bat is hidden behind the central design, his wings projecting 
on either side of it.

The slender trunks of three (?) trees rise in the lower 
left corner of the border design.  The ground to the right bears tufts 
of grass.

The slender trunks of three (?) trees rise in the lower 
right corner of the border design.  The ground to the left bears tufts 
of grass.

A few curving lines to the right of the bird (lower left corner 
of the border design) vaguely suggest vines.

A bird, possibly a cuckoo, stands in the lower left 
margin.  The creature faces right, with wings extended upward, beak 
open, and tongue extended.  It may be singing or crying out.  The talons 
of at least its left foot hold a serpent.

An owl stands in the lower right margin.  The creature 
faces left, with its head turned toward the viewer and wings extended 
upward.  The talons of at least its left foot hold a small mammal, 
possibly a mouse.

The bird in the lower left margin holds a serpent beneath 
one of its talons.  The latter faces right, with mouth open and tongue 
visible.

The owl in the lower right margin holds a mouse—or at least turned or some 
                     such small mammal, such as a vole—in its talons.

Two scrolls, seen on edge, decorate the lower border 
design.

illusobjdesc.#text:
Now at his lowest point, physically and spiritually, Job 
lies supine on a bed or bier and confronts the devil/god of his false 
vision.  Entwined with a serpent and cloven-footed, that god points up 
and to the left with his right hand toward the decalogue; with his left 
he points downward to hell.  Lightning and dark clouds fill the distant 
sky.  Below, two devils reach upward toward Job, apparently in an 
attempt to drag him to the fires of hell below.  A third devil with 
scaly skin holds a chain to bind Job's body and mind.

Job lies supine on a bed or bier.  His legs are together; 
a rough cloth (burlap?) covers his loins.  He is bearded and has long 
hair; his arms are bent at the elbow, with his lower arms raised 
vertically, hands raised horizontally, and fingers slightly spread.  His 
body faces upward, but his head is turned toward us as he looks down at 
                     the fiery pit below.  His open mouth—indeed, his whole visage—expresses terror.  He may be speaking crying out in fear.

Job's false vision of god hovers horizontally above the 
afflicted man.  He is aged and gowned, with long, twisted, and spiky 
hair (rather flame-like) and a long beard.  Only his left foot is 
visible; it is a cloven hoof.  His right arm is raised at 45 degrees as 
he points to the decalogue in the background.  His left arm, raised at 
135 degrees relative to his body, points downward to hell.  He is 
intertwined with a serpent and his lips are parted slightly; he may be 
speaking.  He looks downward toward his victim.

Job's false god is intertwined with a serpent.  The animal 
is scaly, with a protruding tongue.

A devil or demon reaches upward with his right arm and 
grasps Job's lower left leg.  We can also see the claw-like finger of 
his left hand holding Job's lower right leg.  The demon's flesh is 
scaly; he faces upward and his mouth is open.

A devil or demon reaches upward with his left arm and 
grasps Job's upper left leg.  We can also see the fingers of his right 
hand holding Job's upper right leg.  The demon's body appears to be 
intertwined with veins or ligaments, as though his flesh had been eaten 
away by the flames below.  He faces upward.  There is the indication of 
a cuff at his left wrist, but he appears to be nude.

A devil or demon appears below Job's upper body.  The 
flesh of his face and head is scaly.  He faces upward, with lips 
slightly parted.  His hair is short and spiky.  He holds, in both 
upraised hands, a heavy chain.  The claw-like fingers of his right hand 
are slightly spread apart.

The devil or demon lower right holds a 
chain.

The devil/god points toward the stony tablets of the 
decalogue.  A few Hebrew letters appear on the tablet on the 
left.

Dark, stormy clouds and bolts of lightening fill the sky 
above Job's devil/god.  A few cloud outlines also appear below the 
devil/god.

Flames appear above Job's legs and along the lower margin 
of the central design.  In at least the latter location, they represent 
the dark fires of hell.

Job lies on a mat of roughly woven (straw?) fibers which 
in turn lies on a bed or bier of stone or wood.
The borders are filled with flames.
